CO2 is what is used by all the green life to convert the sun's rays into sugars, thereby taking out co2. It's called the carbon cycle.  When you burn fossil fuels you dump far more co2 than what was in the system before. There becomes an excess and the place heats up. text:
For thinking people; ah,the great debate on climate change.¬†One way to test whether this is an honest exchange of facts and ideas is to to seed these sites with facts and ideas that either support the narrative, or contest it, then look to see what sticks and what's removed.

I have done this over the las tweek on at least forty of the major and taking one side or another. ¬†What I found is that usually within 48 hours,anything I say that doesn't support global warming as a crisis is removed, or edited down to only language that is neutral or supportive, while anything posted that would support the argument stays. Makes one wonder where the money is coming from...¬†So, first my honest thoughts about this. 

From NASA:¬† Based on orbital variations, Milankovitch predicted that the¬†ice age¬†would peak every 100,000 and 41,000 years, with additional ‚Äúblips‚Äù every 19,000 to 23,000 years. Three variables of the Earth's orbit‚Äîeccentricity, obliquity,and¬†‚Äîaffect global climate. 

But it's a lot more complicated than that. ¬†And, the last ice age wasabout 30,000 years ago. Interestingly humans didn't do so well because it'shard to migrate and one can show that there were less than 30,000 humans that survived through mitochondrial DNA analysis. Whales, insects and such do muchbetter and have been doing so for 100's of millions of years. 

So, I totally believe in climate change... It's been going on for 100's of millions of years,since planet formation.¬† Long before humans arrived; and yep, the ice capsmelt, ocean levels change and humanity gets huge disruptions, then everything freezes up and people must move south to survive.¬†

The truth is that state-of-the-art weather prediction can't predict the weather next week anywhere on the planet. These computer models make the wrong prediction, 100% of the time. So, before we say these models can predict the next global warming or ice age event, it should work next week.

And, finally any huge heroic effort by humanity to change things one way or another would take another 100k years (one cycle) to measure the effect. ¬†I'll wait a few days and see which if any of my comments survive whoever has time and access to edit or eliminate my input.
author: W. Kurt Dobson

text: When you have no arguments, use emotive stuff such as slavery and cancer. The reason slavery was abandoned was that it was hopelessly inefficient (but sustainable because Africa had a massive and reproducing population), while free market economics (which Puttnam demonises) did things not just more efficiently but also with more humanity. Fossil fuels, by contrast, are extremely efficient, while the preferred alternatives - wind and solar - are hopelessly inefficient. His analogy points to the precise opposite of what he wants us to believe. As for tobacco, it's just a false analogy. We are not addicted to fossil fuels. It does not cause cancer.

text: @anthony matthews: The doomsday predictions about rapid sea level rise from the late 1980s did not eventuate. A lot of scientists seem to have forgotten simple elementary concepts such as the specific heat of water and the latent heat of fusion of ice.  They also fail to understand the difference between convective cooling and radiative cooling. Quality control in science is important. You cannot perform controlled prospective experiments on whole planets and we are therefore stuck with computer models which reflect the biases of the modelers and which amplify errors over time, empirical data and Paleoclimatology research. The computer models are not working well. The sea level is not rising rapidly and Paleoclimatory research indicates that carbon dioxide is not the main regulator of earth's climate. The main regulators are Milankovitch cycles, continental drift cycle and stellar evolution of the sun. Cataclysmic events such as flood volcanism and asteroid impacts can also produce significant changes in the earth's climate.

text:
CO2 is innocent!  At 0.04% of the gases in atmosphere.       at present it is 414.7 parts per million, up from 280 ppm 170 years ago.   Increase is 134 ppm. 
They say that CO2 is increasing by 43% since 1850‚Ä¶‚Ä¶120 /280 x 100 = 43.
Ice cores revealed CO2 levels before the Industrial Revolution were 280 parts per million.
The latest reading taken at Mauna Loa in Hawaii, end of May 2019 was 414.7 ppm.
Increase is 414.7 ‚Äì 280 = 134.7.        134.7 / 280 x 100 = 48.107,  that is 48.2% so they say.
However I question this.  It is not  an increase of 134.7 per se or 280 per se.
It is 134.7 parts per million and 280 parts per million per se.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Next-  imagine a graph with the Y axis   1 km high ie 1 million millimetres,  and the X axis is years  1850  to 2020.  170 years.    
The increase is from 28 cm to 41.47 cm


All this climate alarmism will destroy society, increase taxes and book keeping,  we need not forego our present working practices altogether so fast.  Make improvements yes,  and stop chemtrails, bunker fuel trails in oceans, ionospheric heaters which are forcing billions of volts up into ionosphere, melting arctic and heating up oceans wherever they are active!!!!!    There are plenty of sane climate people  out there.  No need for climate alarm..  It is a trick to force totalitarianism upon all.

text: Care is not a duty. It is in our nature to care of each other. Humans are evolved to act in a communist way. If you see someone drowning - do you thinkt to yourself "hmm how can I profit from this situation?". No, you instinctively act directly because otherwise you would regret it for the rest of your life. What capitalist society and propaganda does is make us believe that we are only a bunch of egoistic individuals and that we are not brothers and sisters. Capitalism alienates us from eachother, creates distrust and rewards things that help the wealthy. The capitalist society says that all things can be bought, even happiness. We have over consumption because we are not happy. Abolish capitalism and it's much easier to save the environment. Join the next environmental protest. I bet you that there are anti capitalists there. Talk to them. But don't just talk. Act.

text:
Is this old man talking about a change in the climate  ?

None of the Climate Hysterics take into consideration that before we had this rise of 1 degree Celsius over the last 200 years - the earth went through a cooling down period that lasted close to 600 years. 

In the early 1300 the climate suddenly got colder, wetter and more unstable and unpredictable.
It was the beginning of the cold period that has been named "The Little Ice Age."
Over the centuries this climate cathastrophy killed millions of people worldwide.

It was the last 250 years of this period that was particularly cold - starting from early 1500 to around the 1880's.  The glaciers around the world grew and expanded to their maximum sizes in modern times.

For the last 150 years or so, we have gradually made our way back heading in a right direction towards having more normal global temperatures.

The UN Climate Panel,  the IPCC,  spells it right out :  they want to reduce the warming, and if possible, go back to the cold climate that we had before the industrial revolution.
That means that they want us to go back to the time when the global temperatures was at its coldest -
some 200 years ago  !

The Climate Hysterics try to frighten you with the world finding its way back to a more normal and warm climate - that has been the average temperatures for the last 10 000 years - ever since the last real Ice Age finally melted away. 
They find this perfectly normal changing of the climate frightening  !

author: T walgoolan

text: ¬†@T walgoolan¬† Hiya T. thank you for your reply. I would like to know where all the extra co2 is coming from, given that there is only so much co2 available on the planet.  No one is making new co2.  Nature has not done anything just so that mankind can survive.  Nature does not love humanity.  All gasses are actually recycled.  For instance, it is known that millions of years ago, the concentrations of oxygen were far higher than today, which resulted in animals and even insects being much larger, followed by climatic events which wiped out life to a great extent.  Subsequent to these events, the levels of gasses were altered, resulting in different lifeforms which were adapted to exist in those environments.  So, given that plants require co2 to exist and the fact that plants exposed to large doses of co2 will actually increase in size massively compared to those plants receiving less co2, could you please explain why we are not completely surrounded by greenery?  Incidentally to this, I want you to know that I do believe that the planet has been damaged by mankind, but co2 is only the latest scapegoat, not the problem.  Our biggest problem is physical pollution and waste.  Most of the figures that are being bandied about come from computer modelling, based on equations that can be made to fit. There are historic records that show that nothing is actually any different from 100 years ago.  The newspaper reports from around the world that describe events with recorded weather that show this.  In the 1970s and 1980s, people were saying that we would be in an ice age by the year 2020.  These articles are easily found in newspaper archives.  There are loads of them from the USA at that time.  Believe nothing you hear and half of what you see and you may find some truth.  If you put me in your fish bowl what will happen is that I will probably eat your fish. (sorry mate, i couldn't resist the last bit) Peace to you.

Please understand, I am not attacking anyone when I make my statements.  Nor, do I want to upset anybody.  I just want everyone to know the truth.  My main reasons for doubt are based on weather records that one of my friends has taken himself in his fishing diaries which go back almost 40 years.  He is extremely precise about everything.  We have learned a lot from reading similar diaries from history, which is where the idea came from.  Tony Heller is definitely worth a look.  You will see that climate is cyclical in nature and you will recognise that billions are being funneled into creating equations that are fit for the purpose of garnering more billions.  A massive racket, just like wars.  Man cannot adjust nature, but can adapt to changes in nature, as they always have.

text:
humans are not the problem because carbon dioxide can not do what the IPCC says it can.  An increase in CO2 without an increase in the few frequencies of radiation that can have an effect on CO2 means nothing in the increase of warming in the atmosphere or anywhere else.  Of the 680 frequencies of infrared radiation between 2.0 and 70.0 micrometers, only around four frequencies will cause the vibrations in carbon dioxide.  None of these frequencies would ever leave the earth's atmosphere even if all carbon dioxide were removed from the atmosphere because other gases cause them to be refracted, reflected and absorbed.
An increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide is caused by an increased in warming (not the other way around).  This fact can be seen in the Ice Core Project data and is the reason Al Gore did not overlay the two charts of historic temperature and carbon dioxide levels in his video.  The over and under sight lines of 400,000 years of records on a chart do not allow fine focus on the details.  You can freeze frame the video and use a straight edge or simply look up the data yourself (ironically, one of the few scientific references that still shows up on the first few pages of a google search -- but that may change in the next decade like other reports have as you start using the data correctly).  The lighter gases rise higher as the heavier carbon dioxide tends to remain in lower elevations.  One lighter gas is water vapor which, during times of higher carbon dioxide concentration, can form clouds at higher elevations.  This has a cooling effect as the clouds reflect incoming solar energy.

text:
ilikethisnamebetter I don‚Äôt care about continuing the planet eating economic machine we have built. There is a 0% chance humans become a positive influence or presence on this planet. Whether we have solar panels or windmills won‚Äôt stop Indonesia from burning the Borneo rainforest to grow palm oil. It won‚Äôt stop Brazil from burning the Amazon for soy and cattle. It won‚Äôt stop Congo from burning their rainforest to grow food. When I tell you the arctic ice was no thicker than 1.5 meters during the September minimum this year, what does that mean to you? Because to me it spells global disaster when the jet stream shifts to center around the remaining ice on Greenland in a few years. Our ability to grow food in mass quantities is over. Crop production in the US was 90% 2 years ago. It‚Äôs down to 55% this year because of all the flooding and non stop rain, drought, and flood again.
Everything they said would happen has happened and it‚Äôs worse than we could have imagined.

author: ilikethisnamebetter

text:
ilikethisnamebetter it‚Äôs not an ideal situation but we‚Äôre about 50 years past all the geologic markers for runaway climate change. It‚Äôs here with a vengeance, and here we are almost in the year 2020 with people like Donald Trump, Boris Johnson, Jair Bolsonaro, Rodrigo Duterte, Narendra Modi, Vladimir Putin, and Xi Xinping running their countries with the intention of setting the planet on fire of it means profits and GDP. I say we live our lives the best we can. There is no stopping the 6th mass extinction, there is no stopping the 8 degrees of warming we could see in a century. The worst predictions 30 years ago didn‚Äôt even come close to the reality of our situation. I‚Äôm just trying to live my life as honest as I can, and that means accepting that human civilization is currently collapsing all around us.
There‚Äôs also zero technology available to us that can cool the planet. Our best hope is to reduce our carbon emissions, there is no such thing as sequestering warmth. The laws of thermodynamics are not on our side.
author: Robert Hollandsworth

text: ¬†@Robert Hollandsworth¬† "Our best hope is to reduce our carbon emissions" - for instance by adopting wind and solar power and electric cars, as I said.
author: ilikethisnamebetter

text:
ilikethisnamebetter and I‚Äôm saying our best hope still won‚Äôt be enough. People don‚Äôt understand what climate change or mass extinction looks like. It looks like 95% of all living things dying like in the 3rd mass extinction where a warming planet nearly ended all life on earth. The oceans have warmed beyond hope. The geologic processes occurring right now like the arctic water boiling with methane are positive feedback loops that will naturally continue to heat the planet for the next 300 years even if we stopped all fossil fuel combustion today. Let‚Äôs say we manage to stop using fossil fuels, what then? None of our economies are working, and the aerosol emissions protecting us from an enormous amount of solar radiation will fall within weeks.
But I‚Äôm pretty confident that world will never happen. Our leaders will step on the gas pedal and send us accelerating off the metaphorical cliff until everything something gives.

text:
It's amazing how many people miss the point of this talk. The man is not a scientist. He did not prepare a speech with scientific facts, because scientists are best suited for that role. And there is overwhelming scientific consensus that climate change exists and is man-driven. His speech is about paying attention to these facts and also paying attention to the fact that there are some very powerful people that have a short-term interest in keeping things as they are, because they profit. And he reminds us of similar past cases. The major difference with this case is that instead of hundreds of thousand of people dying of lung cancer because of the industry lying, it is the world as we know it that is in danger of perishing.
Every one that denies climate change should try and think why it really is that they have this opinion. How have they formed it? Through scientific study? Through reading science journals? Or is it through the opinions of others? Who are these others? Do they have anything to gain by saying this?
My guess is that, as always, people are afraid of change. They are afraid of the changes that will be needed to combat climate change. They are afraid of the extra taxes needed to pay for large scale programs. So when they hear someone discrediting climate change, they want to believe it. But why isn't anyone thinking that it is the richer that will have to overwhelmingly pay for this? They profited the most from the current economic model that polluted the world. So they will have to pay proportionately more to combat the problem. So the poor many should not be so afraid of that aspect. But more to the point, shouldn't people be afraid of the cost of not doing anything? What is it that makes people so reassured that things will not get bad?
Again, this is something for which we have to listen to the experts. And the experts that the human race has created in its intellectual journey through the ages, trying to find the truth about reality, is scientists. Science is what the human race has come up with to give real, provable, testable answers to questions. Few people, of those reading this, I would think, would go to a witch-doctor to treat their illness. Even fewer would stop using their cell phones because they were made by that despicable sect of scientists.
Think about the logic (or lack thereof) of this cherry-picking: I have no problem with using cell phones, aeroplanes, toasters etc. but when it comes to climate change, I will not listen to the overwhelming majority of scientists. Science is not an industry. Coal-mining, car-making, oil-drilling are industries. Do people really believe that thousands of scientists around the world have made a pact and have a vested interest in making us believe in climate change? And do people really believe that the coal, oil and automobile industries (to name but a few) do not have any interest in keeping things as they are?
If so, then there is nothing more I can say.

there have been two temperature spikes similar to today's in the past 400,000 years.  Both times the carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere rose along with the increase in temperature (direct effect of the warming) then fell off much slower than the temperature, which dropped rapidly.  (Ice Core Project data and tree ring studies.)  There's really no evidence that this will not be the same way. 
Hint -- look into how carbon dioxide is affected by radiation and specifically which frequencies of radiation cause any warming.  Then you will not be afraid.  Sorry you can no longer find very many scientific papers on google search anymore -- you'll have to dig to discover what you should know

text:
It looks like a TED talk recommendation for "how to listen" is in order for many of the commentators here...
The REALITY of climate change is that far too little is being done to mitigate it, for all the wrong reasons. A clear and decisive global effort is needed, much like how the general consensus on the health effects of smoking had to be changed, so too must the ramifications of climate change reach the general consensus. Climate change is a problem, the evidence is readily available and the actual effects already noticeable, and the entire world needs to realize this. Regrettably, almost 5 years after this talk, barely anything substantial has been achieved and our sole solution for clean, sustainable, feasible and safe energy is being downscaled rather than implemented across the world. That being nuclear energy (and yes, there's plenty of TED talks providing evidence for that). There is obviously a lot more that needs to be done, but the key message of this TED talk should be clear.

text:
Whether you believe anthropogenic climate change or not, we should look to abandon these fallacious arguments.

I do not believe this man has any malicious intent with his beliefs. I simply believe that he is using bad judgment in his argument.

In no particular order: because nicotine is addictive and the people who owned cigarette companies did not believe in the addictiveness of nicotine; man made climate change is somehow relevant. Because seat belts saved lives but car manufacturers did not believe seat belts worked; man made global warming is some how relevant. The same for the Cuban Missile Crisis. The Iraqi War. Slavery. None of these in any way point to any "reality of global warming".

All these examples are purely anecdotal to when the consensus was wrong, and this is falsely equivalted to the argument of man made climate change and whether we can do something about it or not.

It is funny, because I was really hoping that he would say that the industrial revolution solidified a good thing we did: abolishing slavery. In fact, it seems as though slavery was preventing such an industrial revolution.

I mean; certainly, if the costs of the coastal communities affected by hurricanes is going up - it's either 2 things: the climate is indeed getting out of hand and extreme because of man putting more CO2 into the atmosphere. OR, hear me out, because this might surprise you! More people are living on the coast. Well,why not both? Because we have the data. And the data shows us that the hurricanes are not getting more extreme. In fact weather is getting less extreme in general. It is just that more people are living in environments where extreme weather is likely to occur because the severity is in decline. And when an extreme weather phenomenon occurs, more people are effected, and more people with more developed land means more money is needed to fix the problem.

Instead of looking at the total cost of damages, which is increasing, we need to look at the cost of damage per capita, which is decreasing (adjusted for inflation). "This" is "the reality" of the situation.

It doesn't have much to do with anthropogenic clime change, actually. It has more to do with looking at the relevant data and knowing what is irrelevant.

text:
The Arctic Ocean is warming up, icebergs are growing scarcer and in some places the seals are finding the water too hot according to a report to the Commerce Department yesterday from Consulate at Bergen Norway.¬† Reports from fishermen, seal hunters and explorers all point to a radical change in¬†climate conditions and hitherto unheard-of temperatures in the Arctic zone. ¬†

¬†

Exploration expeditions report that scarcely any ice has been met as far north as 81 degrees 29 minutes.¬† Soundings to a depth of 3,100 meters showed the gulf stream still very warm.¬† Great masses of ice have been replaced by moraines of earth and stones, the report continued, while at many points well known glaciers have entirely disappeared.

¬†

Very few seals and no white fish are found in the eastern Arctic, while vast shoals of herring and smelts which have never before ventured so far north, are being encountered in the old seal fishing grounds.

¬†

Within a few years it is predicted that due to the ice melt the sea will rise and make most coast cities uninhabitable.

¬†* * * * * * * ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†

text: Mr Puttnam seems to forget that the Industrial Revolution in England was based on the "Disregard for human suffering in the pursuit of profit" as much as slavery. That's why poet William Blake described factories as "dark satanic mills"; workers - including children - were exploited to the maximum, to the point that The Luddites smashed factory machines in protest; the Chartist movement developed from that with 6 demands [including the "abolition of the requirement that Members of Parliament be property owners" and that "All men to have the right to vote (universal manhood suffrage)]", etc.. The population was so disenfranchised that In fact - from the UK Parliament's archives: "In June 1839, the Chartists' petition was presented to the House of Commons with over 1.25 million signatures. It was rejected by Parliament. This provoked unrest which was swiftly crushed by the authorities. A second petition was presented in May 1842, signed by over three million people but again it was rejected and further unrest and arrests followed. In April 1848 a third and final petition was presented. The authorities feared disruption and military forces were on standby to deal with any unrest". How very convenient to change history for people who don't know any better, Mr Puttnam...

text: That's a bit of a complicated answer because temperature is different than climate. The temperature of Sweden is gonna be much lower than the temperature of Egypt, right? But both places can successfully sustain human life. Climate is more about how the atmosphere behaves over relatively long periods of time. Due to the accumulation of greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere, global climate is changing because heat from the sun is having a harder time escaping Earth. Due to this change in climate, worldwide temperatures are increasing which changes the weather and livability of many places. For example, agriculture is completely dependent on a region's climate because certain crops grow better in different circumstances. All throughout Africa and Asia, food production is going to plummet due to heat, droughts, and unpredictable flooding. The number 1 thing that we as humans should worry about right now is slowing down climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions. If we do that, that maybe we can prevent the situation from becoming even more disastrous.  ¬†@Adam Eisen¬†

text:
More climate hysteria, fear mongering, and consensus that global warming is caused by man. What is consensus? Consensus is a political term not a scientific term. Consensus means that if 51% agree with the opinion that global warming is caused by man then it must be true! Unfortunately, consensus with respect to global warming ignores reality i.e. facts, cause and effect, and the scientific method.

How about some real hard cold scientific facts about atmospheric CO2? The inconvenient truth is that earths historical record for the last one billion years shows that the average CO2 level was around 2000 ppm and could at times be orders of magnitude higher. Fossil records show massive plant growth in all hemispheres of the planet which in turn lead to huge animal populations and derversity of species. In other words life on earth thrives when CO2 concentration averages 2000 ppm or higher.  During ice ages, the historical record shows that CO2 concentrations could get dangerously below 200 ppm.  Plants begin to die at 200 ppm.  Plant growth nearly stopped and had the CO2 concentration continued to decrease below 150 ppm then all life on earth would have become extinct. Today CO2 is about 400 ppm which is 5 times below the natural average background level of atmospheric CO2. 

Last time I checked man had no appreciable contribution to atmospheric CO2 over the last one billion years... The natural mass of CO2 in the atmosphere is around 750 gigatons . Mans contribution is about 6 gigatons. There is no way such an infinitesimal amount of CO2 could drive earths climate.
author: ecbravo999

text:
"Aha, a consensus of tobacco experts say that tobacco isn't addictive. It must be settled science."

I want to address this comment indirectly because it was made some time ago and I think an independent comment may be seen by more people. The consensus regarding climate science is, significantly, not about whether scientists agree with one another. It refers to consensus of published literature, and by extension, evidence. 97.3% of all peer reviewed papers which express a position on the question of anthropogenic climate change (that is, is it real, and did humans cause it) agree that indeed, the earth is warming and humans are responsible. 

The flagrant dismissal of scientific consensus as "opinions of the experts" misses the critical notion that we are not talking about opinions here, we are talking about the combined evidence and research of every scientific climatological institution on the entire planet. Listen to the evidence.

text: When I stood up in front of a lecture theatre of fellow scientists to deliver my honours project results I was asked to justify a claim that I had made. So I pointed to two stone cold pieces of evidence that strongly supported my theory. If I'd have said "Well 97% of scientists who have looked into this agree with me that I'm right, so just accept it." I'd have been laughed out of the room quite rightly. Having to fall back on nonsense like that shows how weak the theory is. It is completely unscientific to try to use consensus to prove a theory. And regarding this talk, well it's just weird! Yes I do get what he's saying completely but a talk consisting entirely of anecdotes is poor. "My talk is about climate change, so I'm going to mention slavery, tobacco, seat belts, the industrial revolution (ironically based on coal!) the cuban missile crisis, F.D.R., the insurance industry, vietnam war protests, in fact, everything but climate change. Like I said before, I understand his angle. He thinks the science debate is over so he's moved on to what to do next. The problem is that the debate is far from over, it hasn't even begun properly. It has steamrollered the issue to the point that a retired filmaker and non scientist can stand up with complete confidence and self belief and predict such doom as this. text: Nicotine is not addictive. I'm 61 years old and have smoked, on and off, since I was 16. I have never had a problem stopping smoking for periods of time. Sometimes for days. Sometimes for months and years. As of today for example I haven't had a cigarette in about a week. If I have a cocktail sometime in the near future I might have a cigarette. Oh there have been times when I smoked a pack or more a day for years. After this would go on for 10 or 15 years there would come a day when I would tire of it. So I would just stop doing it. In as much as people can be convinced that nicotine is addictive they too could be convinced that global warming is manmade. Now please don't misunderstand me. I am an environmentalist and hate pollution. But the idea that man has changed the temperature of the earth is absurd. Oh sure having a layer of gases around the planet might insulate it in theory. The amount of temperature change from this source is almost insignificant. Ice core samples from the poles have substantiated this. The source of almost all  temperature change is none other than the Sun. The sun's energy output is cyclical. That is why the history of the earth shows ice-ages and warming periods. When we came out of the last ice-age for example there was no industry at all on earth. Yet a period of global warming occured that totally dwarfs what we're seeing today.  So the motivation for this hypothesis is good. Anything which gets the world's attention and causes people to minimize pollution is a very, very good thing. But all this panic about the earth's potential ever increasing temps is totally unwarranted.

text:
I used to believe these claims about climate change until I found out that they never asked climate scientists about the usefulness of carbon taxes and tariffs. Climate scientists agree that CO2 has an impact. They don't all agree that it should be a political issue or that the impact is justification for carbon taxes and tariffs. They aren't skeptical of science they are skeptical of politicians. Here are few good reasons why:

1. Humanities primate ancestors were alive when there was 4000ppm CO2. That's a hard pill to swallow when we're squawking over 400, and good evidence against runaway green house effects. 
2. In the ice core data temperature always changes before CO2 and the lag is thousands of years. So there's no evidence on a geological timescale that temperature would follow CO2.
3. CO2 can absorb all radiation in its spectrum with its current level, increasing it makes it absorb these wavelengths a few meters further up. 
4. Water is the main green house gas by far. It absorbs a wider spectrum of light and because it moves through a huge range of altitudes it insulates Earth much better than CO2 which stays near the ground after it cools from being emitted.
5. Plants are made of carbon and get it from the air. More CO2 could potentially make plant life grow better for that reason alone.  

Teachers in environmental science classes and politicians have all been taught an oversimplified political propaganda. Our best and brightest have been deluded because CO2 does have a hard to understand, but undeniable impact. They just never realized that the impact is minuscule because no one bothered to teach them that. There are other real environmental issues and they usually involve over fishing, over grazing, deforestation, or extinction from habitat loss and toxic pollutants not green house gasses.

text:
Um, let's see if I got it right.   The abolition of slavery forced the industrial revolution upon us and innovation sprung forth as it was previously being kept down by the easy money of slavery.

That's backasswards.   The Industrial Revolution came about at it's own pace, and could not have come faster as much science had to be done first.   The abolition of slavery was at least in part caused by the Industrial Revolution reaching its teenage years as steam engines far surpassed the productivity and profit to be made from slaves. 

A bit more: the increase in European prosperity brought about by colonialism played a big role in funding the science and engineering research needed to bring about the Industrial Revolution.

Doing a moral reversal on history to argue for some kind of new morality is an old trick and folks should be wise to it.

The led lightbulb came rather late, but was only marginally caused by the new morality of sustainability.   Actually, until the mid 90s physicists were almost all convinced that the led could not get much brighter than those little ones used to show that power is on or this or that setting has been chosen.   It was just two senior engineer/researches in, I think, S. Korea that just kept plugging away until one day they figured out a cool trick on the quantum level that gave us bright leds light bulbs. These guys weren't trying to save the world they were just obsessed geeks looking to make a profit.   One has to see that the massive use of fossil fuels creaated the prosperity to fund so much reasearch in  quantum physics that enough had become known so that two geeks could find the missing piece of the puzzle.

Fortunately sci and tech do move ahead somewhat quickly, but they do so only when there is sufficient prosperity to fund it, and solutions just can't be found because they're wanted but some in their own time (as long as there is prosperity).  

You can't forced major changes on society and then safely assume technology will come to the rescue...it may or it may not.  However if the forced changes reduce prosperity then sci tech will slow down.....so don't throw out the baby with the bathwater.

text:
Great emotionally-laden talk. ¬†However, not one scientific fact or premise was discussed. ¬†Rather, we see a demonstration of tying slavery, the ills of the industrial revolution and the evilness of the tobacco industry. ¬†All good points, but it is only indicative of human nature at certain points in time, and has little if anything to do with the evidence for climate change. ¬†



The earth has endured periods of warmth and coldness that far surpass any trends in the last 20 or 200 years. ¬†CO2 levels have been as high as 7,000 PPM vs today's roughly 400 PPM. ¬†

Below are a series of questions I would challenge you to consider in assessing the severity of climate change and the ability to effectively do anything about it. ¬†Here are a set of questions, any of which would lead to the conclusion that we don‚Äôt need to spend a dime on global warming. ¬†I will assume that for each question that we answer in support of climate change. ¬†Just realize that at any point of the questions that a no or not sure invalidates any logic that we should spend billions or trillions of dollars.

Key Questions to Ask about the Truth of Climate Change


1) ¬†Is the world actually warming? ¬†

The earth has actually been in a cooling phase or at least a pause for the last 18 years. ¬†Thus the change to the climate change to further obfuscate the issue. ¬†Hurricanes, tornadoes, and droughts have actually decreased in recent decades, not become more severe. ¬†If we pull back a million years, or even better, a billion years, we see a steady swing of temperature changes that make Al Gore's hockey stick loot insignificant. ¬†But let us say the earth is warming, then the question is:


¬†2) ¬†Is the climate change significant enough to pose a threat to the planet? ¬†

The earth has been going through changes in climate constantly, from seasons to decades to eons. ¬†Normal fluctuations have been occurring forever without humans being the cause. ¬†But again let‚Äôs assume there is some sort of threat that we should pay attention to.


¬†3) ¬†Is the climate change being caused by humans? ¬†

CO2, the culprit most cited by global warming alarmist, is only ¬†400 parts per million in the atmosphere. ¬†The vast majority of CO2 comes from the oceans, decaying biomass, and volcanoes. ¬†Only one-tenth of CO2 comes from humans or 40 parts in one million. ¬†CO2 has ranged from 7,000 parts per million to as low as 180 parts per million - and life survived. ¬†


In fact, in times of higher CO2 concentrations, agriculture flourished, famine was reduced and human advancement increased. Arctic and Antartic ice cores conclusively show over and over that periods of significant temperature rise always precedes the rise in CO2; by many decades or even hundreds of years. ¬†Why? ¬†Because the Ocean, the largest repository of CO2, releases it as temperatures rise. ¬†This leads to massive increases in vegetation which as it dies also releases prodigious amounts of stored CO2. ¬†CO2 continues to rise, as a lagged effect, for decades or centuries after a cooling period has started.



CO2 as a greenhouse gas is a poor retainer of heat. ¬†Yes, it does as a GHG, elevate temperature especially between zero and 400 PPM. ¬†However, it is ever decreasing asymptotic curve of diminishing effect. ¬†It is estimated that a doubling of CO2 to 800 PPM would only have a .7 degree C impact on global average temperatures. ¬†But let us for argument sake say that global warming is real and it poses a threat and it is man-made. Let's not forget that water vapor is by far the most abundant GHG (about 85% of GHGs). ¬†It has far greater impact on heat absorbtion in the atmosphere than CO2

¬†

4) ¬†Is there something that we can practically do to change the threat of global warming?

Short of shutting down all fossil fuel consumption, what is it we can do? ¬†Will better MPG or electric cars (which use energy from electric plants that predominately burn fossil fuels) stop climate change? ¬†Will going to all solar and wind help? ¬†By the way, only about 3% of US energy comes from these highly subsidized yet unprofitable businesses. These technologies do not have the ability or resources to provide the energy needed to run the US economy, and won‚Äôt have it for decades. ¬†If we shut everything down will it make a difference? ¬†What data, analysis, or studies show that a 100% effort by humans would change the natural temperature cycles the earth has experienced? ¬†But let‚Äôs assume we can, next question:


¬†

5) ¬†If there are practical things we can do, are they affordable? ¬† Who is going to pay for all this climate change remediation? ¬†

Do we even have a plan of what actions we would take, what the timeline would be, or most importantly how much it would cost? ¬†What is the plan except carbon taxing? ¬†Will the poorest 150 countries contribute any money? ¬†Probably not. ¬†Will India or China (who both out pollute the US) agree to divert huge national resources away from their growing economies to solve a problem that many believe doesn‚Äôt exist? ¬†

Can the US, which is already $20T in debt have the resources? ¬†All the billionaires in the US only have about $2.2T and all the millionaires only about $19T. ¬†Where does the money come from? ¬†Especially if we want to continue to increase US entitlements? ¬†Trump rightly pulled out of the Paris Accord because the US was being paying ¬†the perponderance of the costs, and countries like China and India were being allowed to continute to pollute. But let‚Äôs assume we can afford it. ¬†Next question.


¬†6) ¬†Do we as citizens of the world have the political will to allow our leaders to effect massive changes that directly affect our pocketbooks, our lifestyles and consumption patterns? ¬†¬†

Would we be willing to go back to the lifestyle of the pre-industrial world? ¬†No electricity, no cars, no iPhones, no lights, no A/C? ¬†Okay, maybe not that drastic - how about limiting car usage, rationing electricity, ¬†moving us all into smaller ‚Äúsustainable‚Äù 1970 era Russian-like apartments? ¬†


If we restrict fossil fuels won‚Äôt people start cutting down trees to heat their homes and doing other unhealthy environmental things? ¬†What do we do when nations ignore the rules? ¬†Do we succumb to a one-world government that has the power and control to force us?

Is it global warming real? Is it a threat? Are humans a significant cause? Is there something we can do about it? ¬†Can we afford to fix it? 

Finally, are we all willing to sacrifice, money, freedoms, and lifestyle to make it happen? It is a lot of ifs, and I for one am not willing to give our government further control of my life on a bunch of flimsy ifs. ¬†Who benefits if climate change is a hoax or is being vastly overblown? ¬†Government! ¬†It gives them more power, more control; and for us, less personal freedom and ultimately, a world dominated by elites and not of, for and by the people.


¬†I am not a climate denier, I am a government skeptic!! Do we need to be prudent proactive stewards of the earth? ¬†Of course! ¬†Do we need to be told to change our lives based on politicized science - not on my watch! ¬†There is no such thing as settled science, that is a non-sequitur.

text:
The fallacy of the 'profit motive' argument is that it could equally well be applied the other way around. 

Globally, we are already spending $1.5 trillion a year on climate change measures. So yes, there is really big money involved here. That makes it worthwhile for those involved to spend heavily on promotion of the climate change agenda. 

The climate alarmists are also very keen to promote the idea that 'Big Oil' whatever that is funds 'Denialism.' Yet, there is not a shred of evidence that it takes place. To the contrary, we know that the renewables industry funds activist groups like Greenpeace to promote their products. The evidence of that is incontrovertible. 

They also campaign to discredit the products of their competitors, like shale gas, with all kinds of propaganda. Now, if that were to go on between two companies in any other sector it would be treated as serious malpractice. But, not here. Why? 

The alarmists seem to think that is OK, presumably because they regard their cause as a noble one. BUT -suppose just for a moment, that it were NOT a noble one, but a self-interested one. What then? 

If the motive is simply one of profit, then it is exactly that which they accuse the oil companies of doing, namely of creating shill promoters of their products. 

Here's the rub: This huge expenditure has had no beneficial effect whatsoever. Carbon dioxide levels are still rising at 
the same rate. Even after 20 years of deployment, the proportion of global electricity from renewables is only 4%. Now, does that make you think again about who is engaging in the profit motive here?

The flood of propaganda from climate activist groups has clouded the minds of the public, such that many can no longer see this situation for what it is. As Morpheus said, "Free your mind.."  

Make your own judgement. You have the power to throw off the yoke of conditioning.

author: Anthony Matthews

text: ¬†@Mridhula Satheesh¬† you have evidently misunderstood what is incorrectly termed 'greenhouse effect'. The sun heats the earth (atmospheric CO2 being transparent to VISIBLE light), the Earth then radiates that heat at invisible infrared wavelengths, of which CO2 absorbs a tiny amount in two limited bands, but then re-emits the absorbed energy, half of which goes upwards. In the meantime, water vapour is doing pretty much the same thing, but over much larger swathes of the infrared band. It also forms clouds, which attenuate visible light to a degree, preventing the sun from warming the ground, but also trapping the infrared being radiated from the ground, keeping the Earth's surface at a more stable temperature.overall. The Earth is not a greenhouse, as it has no 'roof', so convection carries heat into the upper atmosphere, while greenhouses work because the glass allows in visible light, but blocks both convective cooling and radiative cooling by infrared. Ergo, there is no 'greenhouse' effect, and CO2 is not warming the Earth to any significant degree.
author: Ian Hughes

text: ¬†@Ian Hughes¬† I disagree that CO2 is not a major contributor to global warming. Even though it does not trap as much heat as the other greenhouse gases, it is the second most abundant after water vapor. Recent observations and experiments from Nasa show that water vapor can double the effect of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. CO2 does have a significant effect directly and indirectly. CO2 traps heat and we keep pumping more of it into the atmosphere and cutting down more rainforests. The amount of water vapor in the atmosphere is controlled by temperatures, the higher the temperature, the more water that evaporates. CO2 is the second most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and it is a fact that we are contributing to global warming by pumping more of it into the atmosphere. Also, CO2 tends to stick around for a long time if not absorbed by carbon sinks, 300 to 1000 years. Water vapor lasts in the atmosphere for approx. 10 days, that is a major difference. Data shows that the CO2 percentages are much higher than in the last 800 000 years. How is CO2 not a major contributor?
author: Cassandra Frank

text: ...well, 'Cassandra', I don't think there is any way anyone could explain the situation any better than I already have. Also, what is this assertion about water vapour only lasting 10 days? CO2 is a gas only, while water exists on Earth in all three phases; solid, liquid and gas. The ocean covers 70% of the surface, and is continually exchanging vapour with the liquid phase, so the percent of vapour in the atmosphere varies from place to place, and time to time. It also, as I have already said, forms clouds, which block incoming radiation, but also block long wave radiation from the surface, leading to both warming and cooling. CO2 on the other hand only dissolves in water, removing itself from the atmosphere for a very long time, depending on the surface water temperature, which also changes by location, time of day and time of year. There is absolutely no way that CO2 has any significant warming effect compared to water vapour and clouds.
author: Ian Hughes

text: ¬†@Ian Hughes¬† Sir, what I meant by my comment was that CO2 indirectly affects global warming as it, even though less than other molecules, heats the earth which influences water vapor concentrations. There is no doubt CO2 helps increase global temperatures and this, therefore, increases evaporation. I completely agree with the facts you are stating. All I am saying is that CO2 does have a significant effect when you see its effect beyond just its ability to trap heat. For example, CO2 lowers the pH of the ocean. Corals have a very specific pH in which they can live in, and they are home to many marine species. When they die out, these marine species lose their homes and they may also face extinction. This leads to a boom in plankton and micro-organisms that photosynthesize. This will affect other organisms in the area like predators of the organisms that lived in the coral reefs. The boom in plankton also does not last long, as there will be competition in nutrients and because of the death of many marine species, there is no complete nutrient cycle. With fewer algae and photosynthetic micro-organisms, less oxygen is produced. Without these photosynthetic organisms, a lot of the CO2 will remain in the atmosphere for longer leading to more temperature rise and more water vapor in the atmosphere. As you can see, CO2 does have a significant impact.
author: Cassandra Frank

text: Cassandra, your examples do not work. While more dissolved CO2 does make oceans slightly less basic, corals are not particularly sensitive to the pH of the  ocean, and there are other coral species that prefer a variety of temperatures and pH levels, so where one species of polyp is less suited, its place is taken by another polyp that prefers those conditions. Thus your premise is baseless. CO2 has no significant effect, other than to increase plant growth.

text: If you do your best effort to calculate global temperature change per century for EACH of the last 220 centuries (for which reliable global temperature data exists - I'm not talking about just the temperature of Antarctica), you will find that natural climate change (after all, 220 centuries ago Earth was in the depths of the last ice age) occurs at a natural rate of 0.014 C/century on average, with a standard deviation of 0.077 C/century.  Using standard garden-variety statistics, ANY CENTURY that warms by an amount greater than 0.014 + 3*0.077 = 0.24 C/century is NOT NATURAL (or, at least, not usual).  In the 20th century, Earth warmed at a rate of 0.8 C/century.  If you just take the last 25 years and assume that rate continues for the next 80 years, then in the 21st century, Earth will warm at a rate of 2.4 C/century, or TEN TIMES the rate at which ordinary statistics would suggest you are no longer dealing with a 'natural' climate change.  So... food for thought.

text: Puttnam's talk was void of factual information. it was a lot of pablum..."fire bad, water good" sort of stuff. He makes a moral case to take action but action against what? Bjorn Lomborg and Alex Epstein make a moral case for fossil fuel recognizing that even the most extraordinary actions to reduce carbon output (under the assumption that CO2 affects climate) would have a negligible or indiscernible impact on temperatures and in the process, would limit the development of 3rd world countries - countries that need energy and technology to improve health and thereby lengthen and improve the quality of lives. Finally, comparing climate change skeptics to tobacco industry executives charged with the financial health of their respective companies is flawed. They are lying apologists for sure but there are many good-willed scientists, reputable scientists with differing points of view. We need to hear both sides freely expressed and debated rather than shut down because a prominent politician proclaims the science as "settled". Science is not driven by political opinions or consensus. We must let the evidence speak and then make informed decisions in the best interest of all concerned. In my humble opinion Puttnam's talk was a weak expression of personal opinion, void of research and not persuasive...although, he seems like a very nice man!

text:
The issue of anthropogenic global warming has absolutely nothing to do with politics or any political ideology. In fact your apparent assumption that any concern about the threat posed by anthropogenic global warming is based on some kind of a (presumably) left of center political bias is complete and total nonsense. The issue is about science. It has nothing to do with any political ideology. Only in the US with the dominance of simplistic, reactionary political forces like the tea party and the distorted influence exerted on government by Big Carbon (Koch Industries, Exxon Mobil, etc.) along with Canada and Australia (heavily dependent on the fossil fuel industry) is the issue of climate change viewed as political. Elsewhere it is viewed as strictly a scientific issue and rightly so.
BTW I don't give a damn about what you think of movie actors. It's completely irrelevant to any discussion about a complex and critically important scientific issue.

text:
If the global temperature rises then the oceans will evaporate more water.
More water in the atmosphere leads to more rainfall onto land.
More rainfall onto land leads to more plant life.
More plant life leads to less CO2 in the air.

Climate change, if it were man made, would fix itself without any human intervention.
The far more compelling theory for climate change has to do with a natural increase in solar radiation causing the global average to rise by 1-2 degrees celsius. There's also some complicated stuff to do with solar radiation and cosmic rays that have a complex effect on cloud cover, but that's way above my head.

Man mad climate change is perpetuated because all the groups put together and funded to study it would be shut down if they found it wasn't real. It's essentially like a mechanic who goes around at night stealing parts from people's cars so they have to come to him to get them replaced.

text: I base my opinion on the fact that the sun is the driving force of planet temperature. We have just finished a period of solar maximum where the sun spot average was higher for the past 170 years and that corresponds to how long the planet has been warming. Now we are entering a period where sun count will be significantly less which is an indication of lower solar activity. This results in the earth receiving less power per square meter. This in itself will cause cooling but, less activity also means that the earth will receive more cosmic radiation which creates more clouds which will reflect more sun light. Experts range in their opinion to the extent and time frame of cooling from anything from a Dalton minimum  to a Little Ice Age.  The cooling will continue for 30 to 50 years before there is a rebound but the rebound is not supposed to be has high as it has been and then it will plummet lower. That is my reason for believing in planet cooling. Could you tell me why you think it is going to get warmer? Let me add that getting cooler has the potential of causing much more harm than getting warmer. I forgot to mention that during times of solar minimums there is an increase in volcanic action probably due to the sun's magnetic field directly influencing our core. Increased volcanic action just makes cooling more extreme.

text:
No, it's disinformation.   Temperature seeks equilibrium.   The Earth, without changes, stays roughly the same temperature.   When the Earth's temperature changes - there's a cause, and the goal of science is to understand the cause.    Earth's climate isn't "Always changing" it changes periodically, coinciding with forces that drive the change.   This is really basic.   

If there is a cause that's driving an effect, then we have to ask, how bad is the effect?  Is it in our interest to address the cause?   This is prevention vs cure.  It's also really basic.

What Walter said is "happened throughout history" ignores the why and it ignores the effect.   When climate was different 20,000 years ago 1/3rd of America and most of Canada was under a mile of ice?    Do you want that?   Do you think that would be a good chance?   Or Neutral?     By not asking "what will happen" and not asking "Why is it happening", Walter is punting education out the window, content with "Well it's changed before - shoulder shrug" - implying so what.

Walter is wrong.   100%.   It has nothing to do with indoctrination.   It has to do with education and facing reality and understanding that cause and effect are real and worth studying and that it's in all of our best interest to have some basic understanding of this.

Do you hate the truth that much?   Do you hate the future that much?

The Romans didn't live in a "Much Warmer" period than we do now.  That's a lie.

"Generally warmer weather means more trade, yada yada" - depends on the starting point, and it ignores all the harm that's coming with our current rapid climate change.   

There was a brief cold spell in the 6th century, thought to have been triggered by a volcano.   And there was the little ice age - both were hard on Europe, not necessarily hard on the world, though the Volcano probably was for a couple years as it was a global chiller (short lived though).    That doesn't mean rapid warming is good.

Driving to slow causes accidents so driving too fast will prevent accidents?   Is that his argument?   That's not how things work.

So I repeat.  Everything he said was wrong, cept one thing that was a misleading half truth.    And you defended him?   Wow.   You must really hate education.

There has been life on Earth for atleast 4.1 Billion years.  And most of that time there wasn't humans or any other complex life.  The common narrative is to somehow believe that the climate we've known our whole lives is the "default" climate of the earth.

Shitty weather is relative.

Modern man, same skull size, has roamed the earth for nearly two hundred thousand years. During that time, the human population has been severely reduced due to climate change many times. The last during the Black plague, which was climate related. Only recently, one hundred and fifty years, has the population experienced a stable climate. Things will change again, with or without us.

text:
The term "Climate Change" is liable to conceal the reality of the danger. For about two centuries, human industry has been recklessly and at first ignorantly releasing back into the atmosphere carbon dioxide that had been significantly removed in the 60 million years prior to about 300 million years ago. At the beginning of that Carboniferous period, there were no land animals at all.
The "pro-green EU" has an anti-nuclear prejudice almost identical to that which infests my fellow-liberals, democrats, and especially formerly environmentalist organizations, from the Sierra Club to Greenpeace. The NRDC regularly publishes "Benchmarks" of gaseous emissions from electric power producers, the latest of which,  published in 2015, shows that in 2013 as before, nuclear power and hydro provided the only significant quantity of emissions-free electricity, and "other"  renewables were still negligible, even without charging them for the necessity of spinning reserve capacity.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
Dear Sir, 
I'm a concerned scientist and engineer and it bothers me that the term "Climate Change" is vague and mathematically it's very hard to quantify changes in Climate Change over time to answer the important question: is it getting better or worse? Rate of Climate Change change? The derivative of variance of Climate? It's as meaningless as it sounds.

Can we please go back to calling it good old Anthropogenic Global Warming? Then we all at least could have a solid socio-political discussion about costs relative to some measurable climate event. I'm okay with paying a dollar a day, how about those folks living on less than... oh yes. You are aware that they'll be required (by the West) to pay part of the bill, are you not? Their industry stunted so that it never rivals that of the West? I'll forgive 6B people for politely declining to follow your lead on this... in which case more viable solutions are needed.

This won't win me any liberal or conservative brownie points, but in my opinion the solution is to build lots of nuclear power plants. Get the world off fossil fuels and metals by offering an energy (not resource) intensive better standard of living.
author: Doug Hatfield

text: All this talk of science and deniers... science is based on observation and, most important, accepting the reality that is revealed through observation. Even the IPCC and no less than Michael Mann admitted that as the CO2 content of the atmosphere increased, the rate of global warming, which climate alarmists theories say MUST increase as CO2 increases, seems to have decreased, proving beyond any doubt that the measured increase in atmospheric CO2 (we can discuss what is driving it later but SPOILER it is an effect, not a cause) is not the dominant, controlling factor in climate change as climate alarmist theories claim. There are natural forces which are the primary drivers of weather and climate trends and the swings we see, to quote Mann and his fellow climate scientists, are "due to the combined effects of internal decadal variability and natural forcing." ... the rate of warming over the past 15 years (1998‚Äì2012; 0.05 [‚Äì0.05 to 0.15] ¬∞C per decade) ... is smaller than the rate calculated since 1951 (1951‚Äì2012; 0.12 [0.08 to 0.14] ¬∞C per decade). SOURCE: https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/syr/SYR_AR5_FINAL_full.pdf (page 2, bottom, is where it starts) It has been claimed that the early-2000s global warming slowdown characterized by a reduced rate of global surface warming, has been overstated, lacks sound scientific basis, or is unsupported by observations. The evidence presented here contradicts these claims. A large body of scientific evidence ‚Äî amassed before and since the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change indicates that the surface warming slowdown, also sometimes referred to in the literature as the hiatus, was due to the combined effects of internal decadal variability and natural forcing. http://www.nature.com/nclimate/journal/v6/n3/full/nclimate2938.html

text:
NOTE the speaker claims the tobacco executives said Tobacco is not addictive.  That's not what he asked.  He asked IF THEY BELIEVE it was not addictive.    Note how the questioner tries to shut down the guy who states that HE BELIEVES that nicotine, based on all the evidence, does not match the classic (or currently accepted at that time) definition of addiction.  

People with an addiction do not have control over what they are doing, taking or using. 

People who smoke quit all the time.  Clearly this demonstrates control .

MEDICAL DEFINITION:  Addiction is a persistent, compulsive dependence on a behavior or substance.

Do smokers "depend" on nicotine?  Or is it just something that's become a habit that's hard to break because it's part of their routine?  There's plenty of evidence it's the latter.  Something they have become so used to doing that it is done automatically - even those who've quit smoking often find themselves accidentally going through some of the motions related to smoking because it's an ingrained habit, a set of complex behaviors that just became a part of their lives.

Smoking is bad.  I encourage anyone who smokes to quit as soon as they can, for good.  I've lost family members to smoking and resulting diseases.  But it comes down to this:  It's a choice.  They have a right to smoke, as long as they do so in ways that don't expose me and other non-smokers to the negative aspects of their choice, if they wish.  That includes not throwing their butts around everywhere.  Dispose of them safely, properly.

text:
Interesting - he says his subject is climate change but he talks of slave ships and the hated tobacco industry.  

Climate change is real.  There was a burst of warming - but that warming was normal and natural, not caused by humans.  CO2 is a greenhouse gas, but is a bit player, not the controlling force claimed by climate alarmists.  Climate change is real, but it's also INEVITABLE.  Climate is going to change no matter what we do and we cannot stop it - this is the funniest thing about those who  are full of Catastrophic Anthropogenic Climate Change Alarmism.  They're always screaming that we MUST STOP CLIMATE CHANGE!  Good luck with that.

The other thing they're doing is they're lying and they know it - it's their strategy.  To lie so big that people get emotional and lose the ability to think logically, to see the truth.  They're so afraid of the doomsday nonsense they can't think rationally as they panic and have a knee-jerk, reflexive response based on fear.

Relax.  Even if the Arctic is going to continue to melt (probably not) until one summer comes when there's no ice left, it won't be the first time.  And the biosphere did not collapse.  Will some species go extinct?  Probably, but there's no proof they will.  Polar bears have lived through warmer times more than once.  But the point is there is no PROOF that day when there is no ice, during the peak of summer only - it will re-freeze as winter sets in even if it does happen - will EVER COME.  Solar scientists predict the opposite is about to  happen - we are looking at significant global COOLING.  I do not claim they're right.   That may not happen either.  But that's what SCIENCE (not alarmism) says is in our future.

I'll leave you with one of the admitted liars admitting his goal is to lie to motivate you:

"We have to offer up scary scenarios, make simplified, dramatic statements and make little mention of any doubts we might have... Each of us has to decide what the right balance is between being effective and being honest."

Stephen Schneider to Discover Magazine, 1989

text:
Unfortunately, civilian operation of nuke plants have proven to be quite deadly and the present disposal of nuclear waste that is toxic for several millennia paints a very gloomy picture for civilization as we know it.  WPPS in NM already detected leaks from a few barrels of containment.  I served aboard 5 nuclear powered submarines and have watched in amazement at how safe military nuke plant operations were.  In fact the USS Thresher (SSN 593) sank 4/10/1993 with 129 service men and shipyard workers aboard and the implosion destroyed the entire ship but the nuke rods containment vessel was never breached.  The US Navy continues to monitor the wreckage for evidence of leakage but have apparently not found any.  The same can be said of the USS Scorpion (SSN 589) that sank off the Azores in 1968.  Nuke rods remain contained within the wreckage with no signs of leakage.
I say no to more civilian operations of nuke plants.
The Fukushima plants lost containment when the back up diesel generators were swamped and became inoperable causing explosions and containment continues to cause huge issues, included among them is the spread of nuclear waste throughout the Pacific Ocean.  It is the same design as the 104 nuke plants we continue to operate here.  The disaster at 3 Mile Island on the Susquehanna River comes to mind.
The Diablo plant in CA is shut down but is still a disaster waiting to happen.  Attempts are being made to cover plant 4 in at Chernobyl, Ukraine.
Try thinking beyond your clown nose.
author: George West

text:
¬†@Spyros Mitrakos¬† Incorrect. Total deaths per unit energy generated by ANY source is higher than nuclear. That is nuclear in terms of suffering to product ratios is better than everything we currently have at grid scale. Chernobyl (not Chernobil) was a failure of the Soviet Union to be sensible, they used a reactor design that is inherently likely to run away and melt down, did not listen to the engineers that wanted to delay the test and knew the reactor better than the exec, and also designed the reactor to be able to produce bomb grade material (plutonium) hence the design being scary similar to one that can be refueled on the fly for plutonium extraction. 

Fukushima still has a low death toll, a singular wind turbine caught on fire and killed a handful of workers, this turbine (this happened more than once in different places so pick any one of them) has less power capacity in a given year than Fukushima did so not only did it kill more than Fukushima but it also generated less power so the kills to power ratios are way in favor of nuclear. Fukushima could have been avoided by building the plant not in a vulnerable spot, having diesel backups that don't reside under the flood lines so that they work when the facility is flooded, not running that plant past it's maximum life span, and following basic nuclear safety designs. 

CANDU reactors and molten salt Thorium are very promising and the former has a very long and safe record and modern reactors are designed and maintained with VERY strict safety requirements. We can produce safe and efficient reactors but most people hear the work "nuclear" and get worked up. Nuclear is safe unless you give it to a dictatorship that is interested in cost saving, bomb producing, and basically would fail every single operational and design rule on the books or if you allow too much cost cutting at the expense of safety. Essentially if current rules are followed nuclear is the safest and greenst option that produces the least waste per unit energy generated of any other tech we can deploy (hydro I don't know enough on and besides only works in some places unlike nuclear which works anywhere... even under sea in a sub).

Thorium power advocates even endorse the distrust of "plutonium" and "transuranic".
Fast neutron reactors, and perhaps  even the epithermal range in some MSR designs, can consume all of that. One third of the emissions-free nuclear to  electric power that the USA gets, comes from the fission of plutonium naturally manufactured in the reactors. The rest of that plutonium is scheduled, by Jimmy Carter's decree, to be wasted. It really is not bomb grade, and anyway, China and South Korea plan to supply the world with better reactors, the design of which the USA pioneered.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
I'm not going to bother answering the inane questions of the people who think Aggravated Gaseous Waste  (AGW, it's what  causes Global Warming) is a government plot.  It is a fact, and a menace.
I grant without further ado that the official government list of "renewable energy" ought to be thrown in the trash. 
Hydro is dispatchable, but not good for river life. 
Geothermal is marvelous, if you live near the Ring of Fire. The rest is rubbish.
Nuclear power is THE alternative, and the fossil fuel folk know it and fear it.

But global warming is caused by gases, chiefly carbon dioxide, although carbon tetrahydride leaks are tens of times worse. They trap and keep, instead of letting it escape, the energy of the weak infrared photons that surfaces at reasonably comfortable temperatures emit.
That is a few ten-thousandths of the energy with which the Sun irradiates our planet. But if only 99.98% of that energy escapes back to outer space, guess what? The Earth gets hotter. Day and night, year after year, that is a lot of energy. Melted snow and ice represent a very great deal of heat, and so does the uppermost thousand feet of the oceans, at a mere tenth of a degree hotter. Cold water feels far colder than air at the same temperature, and if it's a breeze blowing, you're probably being cooled by slight evaporation from your sweat glands, even if you don't notice.

Wind turbines are a feeble thing compared with the Tall Ships, and the both they and the sail-driven Men-o'War were swept from the seas by coal.
China has the answer, and it isn't the filthy mess they make supplying rare earth metals for the "renewables" trade. See the Daily Mail item on Bautou.

The answer is a diverse field of advanced nuclear fission technologies, the two best  of which were successfully demonstrated in the USA before the disgraceful Chernobyl meltdown, or the Tohoku earthquake disaster. No, Fukushima's reactors were a grievous loss, but the killed nobody. It is hysteria and pro-fossil fear-mongering to call that a disaster in comparison even with the deaths caused by  the unnecessary panic and flight from the reactor location.

author: Edwin Rydberg

text:
To those afraid of climate change and critical of 'deniers', I ask this... if you're so afraid, what are you doing about it? (remember, recycling still uses energy and creates harmful bi-products, not to mention the gas-guzzling trucks used to pick up the waste).

Are you getting rid of your electrical gadgets?
Are you avoiding the use of all cars, buses, trains, planes?
Do you rely only on blankets for heating (no electrical or gas)?
Only use non-petroleum-based waxes for light? 
Do you boycot places that have the heating or air conditioning turned on?
Have you stopped wasting paper from wrapping Christmas or birthday presents?
Have you stopped giving greeting cards?
Have you stopped buying presents or stuff you don't need (virtually everything you buy, most of it made overseas and transported to you).
Has there been a huge outcry against the vast amount of junk mail?
Have you stopped wearing clothes made and shipped from half-way around the world?
Have you stopped eating non-locally grown foods?
Have you stopped drinking bottled water? or any other bottled/canned drinks?
Have you stopped eating any packaged foods?
Have you stopped eating in restaurants?
Have you stopped going to conventions?
Stopped going to school?
Stopped staying in hotels?
(the last three are all unnecessary uses of electricity and gas, not to mention the waste in the construction of their buildings).
Have you stopped watching television?
Have you stopped using computers, or surfing the net? Or watching YouTube?

Because if you truly believed this was as serious as you're telling us, and that it could lead to horrible disaster for everyone, that it's equivalent to 'smoking for the planet', then you'd do all of those things first, yourself. Only then would you get everyone else to follow. But somehow, I suspect all of you still manage to convince yourself to use a car/bus/train/plane, or your mobile phone, or watch television / YouTube... So, until you can honestly say you're not being hypocritical about this, you may want to STFU because if the 'problem' is really so serious, half measures won't do.

Now, feel free to tell me why you, like Leonardo DiCaprio, feel you should be the single exception on the planet to the necessary hardships.
author: Edwin Rydberg

text:
I no longer believe sustainability is our best way forward. Think about it. Sustainability means equilibrium. Biochemically, equilibrium means death. At the very least, equilibrium of our society means the inability to move forward. And that means we will doom ourselves to stay on the Earth until we go extinct.

The only way forward for the human race is to give up this idea of sustainability (not synonymous with clean energy, by the way) and push for extraterrestrial colonization as fast as we can (there are vast resources out there anyway). If we don't, we will either kill ourselves off, or die off slowly while locked in a state of perpetual recycling, gradually degrading our useful resources while we think we're saving the planet.
author: Edwin Rydberg

text: We are not the first generation to experience the effects of climate change as Mr. Puttnam asserts. Climate is constantly changing. This has been shown by analysis of ice cores, tree ring data, stalagtite formation as well as other methods. Just look back a few hundred years to the " Little Ice Age ." This was a period of rapid global cooling that occurred before humans were releasing large amounts of CO 2, particulates or other gases into the atmosphere. There was a period of global warming approximately 2000 years ago that was again before we had the capacity to release large amounts of gasses into the atmosphere. I don't dispute that humans are having some affect on the atmosphere, but it is minor and insignificant. Many unbiased scientists have realized this for years and are now speaking out. This hoax on the world was created to exert more control over our wallets and our lives to the benefit of the very rich and powerful. text: An image came to mind: frogs in a pot on a burner arguing about the water temperature as it rises. There is a certain futility to that image. If you're living every day like it might be your last, making peace where you can, putting self-awareness first, then you're likely doing all you can. You're stepping out of an extremely punishing economic system, both for humans and other creatures on the planet. People often think the earth is a dead, inorganic thing from which living things arise. What if the earth, itself, is a living sentient 'being' of a different order, a planetary order; what if we're guests and it's the host? Maybe it's decided our jig is up. We've become more like an infection now, and a planetary 'fever' is the response. Human beings only pretend to be nice to each other to avoid negative consequences or for self-gain. They are vicious animals that think nothing of enslaving/ running rough shod over one another. They behave ruthlessly and rapaciously in the name of profit, are greedy and petty. A few of them own almost everything, while a great many go hungry or without. And to a greater or lesser extent we as individuals are complicit. Let me state that another way: none of us are innocent. Ignorant perhaps, but not innocent. In our collective vanity we somehow think we can survive, but our time on this globe is likely limited in spite of what we do now (that doesn't mean we shouldn't try). If so, the thing to do is to make harmony and spread peace wherever we can, and stop punishing others as well as ourselves. Most of all stay present, and worry less. Peace out.

text:
current carbon concentrations average in the 300's  ppm, plants evolved at concentration far above that and the ideal concentration of carbon for plants is ~1000 ppm. before humans started burning coal, carbon concentrations which ranged in the 200's ppm was steadily declining. once it hit around 150 ppm, no plant would be able to survive and all complex life would cease. 

by us releasing carbon back into the atmosphere, we are literally saving all complex life on the planet.  according to a study published in the journal nature, there already has been a 25-50% increase in greening on vegetated land since 1982. 

furthermore, all the proposed models have not reflected reality so far. according to the models the warming should be accelerating, for which it is not. 

but even if the worst proposed scientific scenario were to occur with climate change, it has been shown that it would be significantly cheaper to adapt to rising sea levels, then to prevent it.

if global warming is huge issue that we must prevent, the very first thing we need to do is to reduce general consumption by the people, and by far the best and most effective way to do this, is to reduce government spending. but how much environmentalists do you see proposing that, why instead they all support increasing government spending?  

modern day environmentalism is like a watermelon, green on the outside, socialist red on the inside.
