text:
So, I go to your site mentioned above and watch the entire video called: ‚ÄúGlobal weirding with Katharine Hayhoe: Episode 6‚Äù.  Thank you by the way, I‚Äôll keep an eye on that site above.  I have two separate takeaways,  as my first impressions of this site.  Please read BOTH below.

First, here is my problem.  In the first few moments in the video, I hear that ‚Äúflood insurance in Minnesota tripled over the last 20 years‚Äù.   So it gets me thinking and searching the internet for more information.   For example, I‚Äôm asking myself, what has the population done over the past 20 years?  What has the median home values in Minnesota for past 20 years?  Both are easily up.  I also see lakeshore properties are increasing.  So I decide there are no clear irrefutable facts here. The climate change folks need to provide better science in general here.  The issue comes across as how someone feels about it. We need more FACTS.

But wait there is more‚Ä¶

I did learn about ‚Äúurban heat islands‚Äù also in this video.  I‚Äôm reading the wiki on ‚Äúurban heat islands‚Äù and doing more studying here.  This ‚Äúurban heat islands‚Äù is one I‚Äôve not heard anything about.  I have often felt the effects of it myself but it really never registered as anything of a concern.  It makes clear sense to me and has been studied since the 1800‚Äôs I read.  Wow, now there is some science and ‚Äúgreen‚Äù in that ‚Äúurban heat islands‚Äù that I could easily get behind and support. Oh, no.¬† you're lack of basic science is showing again.
"Firstly Venus's atmosphere is more carbon than anything else"
I am going to assume that what you meant by carbon was actually carbon dioxide.
But that proves the point.¬† the reason venus is so hot is because it's atmosphere is mostly co2.¬† Duh!

Not only do you not know much about science, but apparently not know much about basic math.
Human carbon footprint is way more than 10%.¬† where did you get the 10% figure from anyway?¬† just plucked it out of....?
Currently co2 levels in the atmosphere are 400ppm.
Preindustrial levels were 280ppm.
to work out % increase, (400/280)-100=42%
Given that some of that co2 increase would be from volcanic activity, which is about 1% of what humans pump into the atmosphere each year, but let's be generous and say 2%.¬† 
So humans co2 foot print is 40%, quite a bit more than 10%.

Co2 is 0.04% of the atmosphere by volume.¬† but 99.95% of the atmosphere is Nitrogen, Oxygen and argon, which are not greenhouse gasses.¬†¬†¬†of the 0.05 left most are greenhouse gasses, & most of it is co2.¬†

Martin Hearn 
Well it's great that you agree with NOAA's research because none of it points to human caused carbon emissions raising Earth's temperatures by any significant amount.
It's also interesting that you ignore the fact that ocean's aren't creating all of the O2. Plants (being over 98% of them) cannot exist without photosynthesis whose byproduct is O2. Carbon gas saturation is quite high but this benefits large plants on land as well as plankton in the ocean's and algae in lakes and swamps all over the planet. Why? Because these plants need carbon to keep photosynthesis functioning smoothly. The increased carbon saturation is benefiting plants and has sparked increases in plant growth.

It's also interesting that you completely ignored my post looking at satellite reliability. Personally I thought satellite data was too low resolution, but apparently their just completely incompetent as measuring tools according to the people in the video I linked yesterday.
It's fascinating that we have approximately forty thousand weather stations most of which are in human cities and farmland including the nearly six thousand ocean bouys... For MILLIONS OF CUBIC MILES OF OCEANS!
Alaska alone is over 1 million square miles of land and how many weather stations do they have? 30? 300?
Radar isn't exactly a good thermometer (it's actually a damn terrible thermometer)!

Recap: plants on land contribute to atmospheric O2 levels quite a bit, NOAA's data and climatologists are undecided about what causes abrupt climate change but are pretty certain that humans didn't cause any of the changes in the 80,000+ years depicted by ice core research, and satellites are pure crap or absolutely vital to proving global warming is real or a total overreaction depending on who you're listening to at any given moment.
Basically the only concrete data we really can all agree on is that CO2 levels are rising and as I mentioned CO is what is pumped into the air not CO2. Catalytic converters don't turn CO into CO2 magically. There's a fair bit of CO in automotive emissions (all vehicle types except full electric and hydrogen fueled vehicles). Carbon gas regardless of atomic configuration is significantly heavier than air which is how it will always finds its way to our ocean's and is absorbed by plankton which then metabolize it as these sometimes single-celled organisms process the gas they can also replicate themselves. This can be a driving force in algae blooms. Unfortunately algae blooms are too big to be consumed as a result these creatures die and sink in huge heaps to the ocean floors. This by the way is where the pH increasing carbon is likely coming from.
But their's another snag in the US some companies aren't allowed to pump very much carbon gas into the atmosphere... In the US carbon emissions are taxed a lot! It's not in big industries best interests to pump out so much carbon gases. In America the emissions are slowly declining and yet the carbon saturation keeps climbing.
We're doing our part tye rest if the world isn't and there isn't a damn thing you or I can do about it. The icing on the cake is that carbon emissions don't seem to be directly impacting the temperature globally. Remember satellite data is showing cooling which is inaccurate because of friction in LEO which is also affecting total orbital velocity and temperature collection timings allegedly. So what are the global averages as measured by everywhere on Earth?

No climatologists have an answer!

Global warming right now is as real as God in the sense that we can't prove or disprove it's existence in any conclusive manner. As I said loads of anecdotal evidences and research that we don't have nearly enough data points all satiating confirmation bias on either side.
The pundits are talking the businesses are actually fixing the issues and the data still suggests nothing is changing while cities grow and resources become more scarce the media perpetually reminds the weak minded that this is all the fault of a gas that is being cut out of modern western industrial emissions!
Do I need to go on?

"Q3: What data are used for U.S. land surface temperature monitoring?
NOAA maintains a network of thousands of stations, many of which have volunteer observers. A subset of 1,219 of these stations in the contiguous 48 states make up the U.S. Historical Climatology Network (USHCN). This dataset has undergone extensive quality control and corrections to remove biases. One of the differences between USHCN and GHCN is that for U.S. data, we have access to detailed station history information which is used to guide part of the bias removal process. Additionally, the new, high quality U.S. Climate Reference Network data are used to verify recent years of the USHCN analysis."
https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/monitoring-references/faq/temperature-monitoring.php

text:
Martin Hearn 
Well it's a good thing I didn't respond to your first comment.
Plants metabolize the toxic carbon dioxide gases and turn that into O2 through their cellular respiration process. We humans exhale CO2 because we metabolize O2 through a cellular respiration process. The iron in the hemoglobin proteins of red blood cells are good at bonding with O2 but much more importantly our cells can use O2 to keep cellular functions going. The O2 is converted into CO2 which also bonds very easily with hemoglobin and is pumped back through the circulatory system until it reaches the lungs and is exhaled along with any amounts of unused gases breathed in earlier.
CO2 is critical for plants survival. CO2 exists in our atmosphere in very small levels clearly the amounts we constantly pump into the atmosphere aren't killing us directly. If they did we wouldn't be having this conversation now, would we?
author: VariantAEC

text:
Chill Hammer 
Ultimately the things people can do to curb pollution are very simple... So simple you could argue it should be innate. Not using more than you need is a great start. Unfortunately the biggest polluters are corporations. Not saying corporations are the big bad evil guys the world needs to fear, but in some ways their daily operations and poor oversight are destructive to the ecosystem.
Not every corporation treats this issue the same. Some are very strict and don't allow for much waste to escape their confines and some don't care much about where their waste goes. However no matter how a company monitors it's waste once it leaves their sight the buck is passed to another corporation that will have slightly different ways of monitoring and treating the waste.
It's exactly the same as throwing out your garbage and waiting for the trash truck! What happens after your own trash leaves the curb is likely unknown to you.
Even if you work in waste treatment or recycling you don't know who will buy the recycled goods or how they will monitor their waste.

It's pretty interesting when you look at the bigger picture. Makes you wonder how anyone country could possibly tackle the issue on a global scale. It just won't happen unless a good cheap example is proposed and practiced with demonstrable proof of benefits for any given company. Governments wouldn't even need to force regulations if companies can profit from efficient recycling programs.

I just want my children's children and following generations to be able to enjoy earths beauty. It's a topic that's hard for anyone to disagree on.
author: Chill Hammer

text:
Chill Hammer 
Laws limiting the use of plastics...
That wouldn't work. How would you like to limit the very things your cereal, headsets, phones, games, sterile medical equipment among a huge variety of other things come packaged in or are made out of?
Instead more incentives for recycling need to be found. Plastics aren't recyclable. I always find myself asking why not? Most of the plastic things we own were made using injection molding... That means the plastic was melted down there are bits and pieces that get cut off or shaved down. In almost all cases this excess or waste is melted back down and reused until there is too little left. So most of the plastics in our electronics could be reused, however it simply isn't.
Also plastics aren't the enemy of the environment. People are. It's like arguing that guns kill people. They don't until an another person loads a bullet into the chamber aims it at someone and pulls the trigger.
If one company turns a decent profit by recycling excess waste it's probability of catching on will increase by leaps and bounds.
People on an individual level are also part of the problem. So many Americans still don't quite understand what trashcans are for. I see it all the time. If you're an American I'm pretty sure you'd agree that you'll be hard pressed finding a place where people haven't already made a mess of things.
People's habits and corporate greed plus lack of immediate feedback as to why people need to clean up is why the ecosystem is the way it is. People have a habit of taking things for granted and not giving a crap about the bigger picture.

There is only enough data to tell us that in the past 80,000 years atmospheric carbon saturation is at it's highest level in Earth's history. But the lovely scientists working with ice cores are also saying this is the most reliable data available, but it's not perfectly accurate.
That said America is cutting down it's up to other countries to follow suit and it's also worth mentioning that there are plenty of times in Earth's history that included heat without excessive amounts of carbon gases diffused throughout the atmosphere.
We don't know what caused the abrupt warming trends, but it's safe to say that most of the world was impacted by these spontaneous abrupt changes in average temperatures all well before recorded human history.
I personally don't subscribe to man-made climate change.

author: VariantAEC

text: VariantAEC - if I give you concrete data that your neighbourhood had no break-ins, no home invasions, no car jacking, and no petty theft, would you immediately on the basis of that evidence stop locking your car, stop locking your home, disconnect your alarm system, and demand from car makers and home builders to stop adding locking mechanisms because of the unnecessary costs?  Regardless of how concrete my data is, everybody understands that locking your car, locking your door, and having an alarm helps to change the probabilities in your favour to protect you from loss.  Theft is unknowable, and because it is knowable, you choose the action that makes the assumption that theft will eventually happen and lock your house/car.  The same applies to investing.  Many understand that performance of stocks are unknowable, DESPITE data collected from stock markets, complicated algorithms, and measure of risk.  People spread their investments, and shift their investments increasingly to more conservative investments as they get older because A) no one knows when the big losses are going to come, and B) the older you are, the less time you have recover from loss.  The situation with the environment and climate is no different from investing.  The climate, like the stock market has its surprises, and the farther in time models project, the bigger the error.  However, we do know that CO2, regardless of source is the source of the greenhouse effect.  We have an example in nature other than the Earth - its Venus.  It has the hottest surface temperature even though Mercury is closest to the Sun.  Venus is the endstate of any planet with an atmosphere where CO2 reaches a certain concentration.  Air samples in ice cores show CO2 peaks in concentrations correlating to volcanic eruptions over tens of thousands of years, and we see a general rise in CO2 after the Industrial Revolution.   The surface temperature AVERAGE has not moved much but the DIFFERENCE in surface temperatures has increased which indicated a general rise in energy introduced into the atmosphere.  We may not have concrete data on where all the carbon comes from, and we may not have enough thermometers to get more accurate models, however, its clear we as a race don't know where the point of danger lies, yet we do see evidence that carbon emissions can cause problems.  So I ask, is it WISE to assume nothing is wrong and keep doing what we are doing?  Let me leave you with this final point.  Humanity survived the savannah, not because humanity used the scientific method to determine conclusively the nature of every sway of grass.  Humanity survived by making decisions in the face of very incomplete information by ASSUMING the sway of grass contains a lion and best not to run the experiment to figure out why.

Joe Almeida 
First your analogy falls flat on it's face from the get go. My neighborhood isn't the whole world. The data I provided you with is that which indicates "the whole world's" temperature but it clearly isn't. The averages are what's changing not the total difference in highs and lows. The temperature from day to day is highly variable and as an average based on the stations it is increasing. Based on the satellite data the global temperature is decreasing. Based on a single video I was able to find the satellite data is inaccurate, but I couldn't find anyone who agrees with the content of the video stating satellite data is inaccurate. The land based weather stations are in highly urban areas most of the stations are at metropolitan airports. Perhaps it's a coincidence that airports have higher CO2 concentrations? I mean who am I kidding jet engines don't emit any CO2 at all!!!

People don't know where the data comes from... Most don't care and this is a pretty big problem because the data the media uses is pushing a global warming agenda. There have been studies suggesting that the added CO2 is actually good for living plants. The more unbelievable studies suggest that the added CO2 will stave off another "little ice-age".
The more reasonable data backed by tried and true observations and scale experiments suggest that humans would ned to add several orders of magnitude more CO2 emissions than we do now to adjust the temperature by a few F¬∞ and that it would put the CO2 concentration to intolerable levels (would make animals sick and possibly kill via a very slow kind of suffocation). The thing is as CO2 concentrations rise the temperatures actually stabilize because only some wavelengths of light from the sun will attenuate and only to a certain degree before losing its energy. It the temperatures can only keep climbing if the atmosphere fills with other forms of gas. Hey doesn't Venus have loads of methane in it's atmosphere? Why yes it does. Methane is worse than CO2... Want to know what's worse than methane and CO2 combined? Water vapor. That's right simple water vapor increases air temperatures far more than CO2 or Methane. You would need suffocating clouds of Methane and CO2 and still not wind up with the same amount of light to heat converting power of atomized water!
So far those studies have proved pretty accurate even on very large scales - like in Earth's atmosphere.
It's warmer in winter without any wind and dense cloud cover than without wind and without cloud cover. The ambient humidity drives temperatures up. Concrete and pavement hold onto the converted light energy of the sun and slowly release heat all throughout the night artificially driving temperatures up... Where don't we see concrete and pavement? Where people haven't placed cities! AKA no where near most of the world's airports!

author: Gavin Sherlock

text: You've missed my point entirely.  I'm talking about making decisions in a world where the future is opaque.  Regardless of how good the data that comes from the police about neighbourhoods and low likely probablility of theft, people still lock their door.  The lesson here is you make a decision in the face of incomplete data where the outcome is in your favor.  That's it, nothing more to read into it.  Nobody knows for certain what will happen with high confidence because the system is so bloody complex.  Data is meaningless.  It doesn't matter, because the wise course of action IS to cut down on carbon emissions.  Life existed at lower concentrations of CO2, and it existed for over 3 billion years without man doing its civilization experiment.  That we know.  What we dont know is what things will look like at 800ppm or 950ppm.  The concentration CANNOT go on forever.  Nobody knows where the danger point is, it is all speculation.  So in this case, where nobody knows the future, but you know that there are limits and things are approaching those limits, do you just do nothing?  I don't trust models of either the climate scientist or of the climate denier.  All I care about is the potential risk.  Do nothing, nothing may happen, or things go to hell and we learn of the point of danger AFTER THE FACT, or, we make choices, make investments, and manage our carbon emissions to keep the levels in a zone where we know life has existed.  The burden of any proof lies with the climate deniers because of the simple fact life existed for a very long time without the influence Civilization and its emissions.  Mankind and its civilization is the one that is running the experiment, that is living in a way completely alien to the way any other creature has biologically evolved.  We have no other planets we can observe that have creature like us, running industries like us, to know what will truly happen.  We will never have the data needed, and we will never truly know where the point of danger will come.  What we do know is the planet is finite, the atmosphere is finite, our resources are finite, CO2 traps heat and the ppm of CO2 is building.  Heck, money is a finite resource, and how do we manage money - we create budgets to set targets of what to spend.  The truth is, nobody wants to do anything because its going to represent changes to peoples lives and they simply don't want to think about it.  Data is not the problem - we all know deep down what the proper and WISE course of action is, its just that we cannot imagine what life would be like in a non-carbon future because we are too comfortable with the current situation.  Final point, Time will tell if the activities of civilization will make the climate unstable.  If Im wrong, Im wrong and life goes.  If I'm right, then my next prediction is Nature will fix the problem for us, by creating conditions that will wreck civilization and scale us right back down.  Let hope I and others are wrong seeing as how many are incapable of acting on true wisdom.

author: MrRobtwothirds

text:
+VariantAEC

"The data is skewed towards showing small increases in temperature because the majority of the official numbers come from densely populated and frequently used American and foreign airports."
"The exact opposite. The temperatures from rural stations should be relatively flat (unchanged averages). That would indicate that there is no global warming this would be further strengthened by the fact that rural areas are usually surrounded by more densely populated areas. If these zones show no significant increases in average temperature then global warming itself must be false. It's called a qualitative study."

You're offering another standard denialist talking point about the urban heat island effect (UHI). 

The temperature records are not primarily from urban areas; there are, in fact, many temperature stations in rural areas, and temperature proxy records from cold regions (especially ice-covered regions where people can collect ice cores).

When you look at rural sites, there's statistically significant warming. When you correct for any UHI, there's still statistically significant surface warming and most of the observed surface warming remains; so the UHI does not work as an explanation of the observed surface warming. And there wasn't really a statistically significant difference in the warming trend between rural American stations that AGW denialists like Antony Watts like, and stations denialists don't like.

Here are some scientific research papers to get you started, providing evidence for the points I made above about the UHI and temperature rise:

"Influence of Urban Heating on the Global Temperature Land Average using Rural Sites Identified from MODIS classifications"
"Global rural temperature trends"
"Quantifying the effect of urbanization on U.S. Historical Climatology Network temperature records"
"Earth Atmospheric Land Surface Temperature and Station Quality in the Contiguous United States"
"Urban heat island effects on estimates of observed climate change"
"A Demonstration That Large-Scale Warming Is Not Urban"
"Assessment of Urban Versus Rural In Situ Surface Temperatures in the Contiguous United States: No Difference Found"
"Urban and rural temperature trends in proximity to large US cities: 1951‚Äì2000"
"Urbanization effects in large-scale temperature records, with an emphasis on China"
"Urbanization-related warming in local temperature records: a review"
"Evaluating the impact of U.S. Historical Climatology Network homogenization using the U.S. Climate Reference Network"
"On the reliability of the U.S. surface temperature record"
"Urbanization Effects on Observed Surface Air Temperature Trends in North China"


So how about you drop your denialism, and actually change your position in response to the evidence?

"It is, however, important not to confuse denialism with genuine scepticism, which is essential for scientific progress. Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not."
http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full

author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text:
+tialoose, really? Poor critical thinking is the problem. Let's take your statement piece by piece. Temperature increases of even the last 14 years. Here's NASA satellite data which is the Only truly global temperature record for the planet, produced by 2 climate scientists (one a former lead scientist for the IPCC, and the other a former NASA scientist):

http://drroyspencer.com/latest-global-temperatures/

I'm writing this in December 2016, so the graph currently ends November 2016. Over the last 37 years, temperature has increased 0.7C. Whoopee! We're frying! (Not!) During the time period I mentioned in my opening comment -- the end of the Younger Dryas -- global temperatures shot up as much as 7.0C in 30 years! That's 10x faster and in a shorter period of time. And that made civilization possible.

"...we humans have spiked that change into hyperdrive..." If you look at the work of Alley (2000), his GISP2 ice core temperature proxies show that the Holocene has had 10 warm periods, 1 every 1,000 years or so. That's 10 natural warm periods; not 9 natural and 1 human+CO2. Yes, you acknowledged that nature still plays a part, but here's the kicker on this data: the Modern Warm Period is the Coolest of the 10 warm periods! Not only that, the trend for the last 3,000 years has been strongly toward cooling. When you take the deep and broad cold of the Little Ice Age (between the far warmer Medieval Warm Period and the Modern Warm Period), these facts suggest that the Holocene has already started to shut down in favor of the next glacial period of the current Ice Age. The work of W.S. Broecker (1998) shows that our Holocene interglacial (warm phase of an Ice Age) is already older than average and overdue to end. So, you're wrong. The Modern Warm Period warming is not spectacular; in fact, it's substandard.

Medieval Warm Period warmer than today? Yes! Even in 2016, we still can't grow crops where the Vikings did in Greenland. We still can't grow wine grapes in England where the Medieval farmers could. During the far warmer Holocene Optimum, the Sahara was green, because plentiful rain made deserts more scarce or smaller.

Do we humans create problems with the environment? You bet we do. Publicly trade corporations are evil and will always be selfish. And you still get your news and science from them? Tsk, tsk.

I used to be on your side of the fence, and then discovered that Al Gore and I had been horribly wrong. Did I hit my head against the wall to wake up to this new realization? No. Simple logic and enough humility to admit that I was wrong. Try it sometime.

author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text:
The atmosphere of this planet did not merely "change" a billion years ago.Before that time it was unutterably hostile to probably all multicellular life. During the age when the fossil carbon was being laid down, and to some extent perhaps for a billion years previously, it became hostile to all previous organisms of the sort we call "anaerobic", like Clostridium botulinum .
The correct term is Anthrpogenic Global Warming, and in particular it refers to an ongoing increase in the energy stored in the oceans, by the fact that GHGs especially CO2  and CH4, interfere to even a fraction of a thousandth, in the necessary balance of incoming and outgoing energy.

text:
Who cares anymore whether it's the fault of the human animal with it's frailties and limitations, or if it's mother nature showing off her guns?
When it comes to global warming and it's consequences, including climate change and it's effects, all I care about is that it is happening!!!
And you don't have to be a scientist to research all the information out there to come to the following facts:
Fact: Biology 101: The human animal can't exist without habitat.
Fact: No human has existed above a 3.5 degree increase in the past.
Fact: The CO2 emitted into the atmosphere in the last 10 years hasn't been felt yet. There is a minimum 10 year lag.
Fact: Our oxygen comes from plants (forests) and the oceans
Fact: Our plants (forests) and oceans are dying
Fact: Global oxygen levels have decreased by a minimum 30%.
Fact: There are 150-200 animals going extinct every day.
Fact: Year 2100 climate models do not include effects of methane.
Fact: Abrupt climate change has been triggered due to release of arctic methane.
Fact: The past has shown a 5 degree increase over a 13 year period.
Fact: 2 + 2 = 4 + degrees = Near term, not long term, Human Extinction
Fact: To deny any of the above, or to provide misleading information is to disrespect all the humans on this globe.

Fellow human animals of the world, I wish you the best in the next 20-30 years. 
Be good to each other, and live life the way YOU want to live in the best way you can.
The human animal has had a great journey. 
As much as it is sad to see it ending for us, take solace in that none of us will be alone.

Food for thought: Instead of living in denial of impending death, think of it in the larger sense.
We all knew we'd die at some point, in some way...so other than the timeline....what's really changed?
From my perspective, the story of the human animal on this world, as brief on the geological time scale it will be, has been an amazing one.
Knowing there are only a few decades at the most left, gives me the opportunity to be truly free.
I hope it will do the same for you.

text: There is clear evidence for climate change, looking back at past climate events we know that global temperatures have never been higher than it is now, even the last glacial periods where the earth was cooling, was actually warmer than the previous glacial period. Evidence from ice cores, dendrochronology and historical records prove this. As we are now in an interglacial periods, it is expected to be warmer, however, this increase in global temperatures is unprecedented, we can blame natural causes all we want but that does not change the fact that there is a clear correlation between the amount of CO2 emitted and temperature increase. Lets NOT bury our heads in the sand, this problem will not go away if we simply sit back and do nothing!

text: But at what cost? Read the book "Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind" by Yuval Noah Harari to gain some insight at how the human species have already changed the face of this planet, driven many species to extinction and might very well within the next 100 years make the planet unsuitable habitat for any mammals. Many think of progress as what we define as our western lifestyles, but fail to regard all the external costs of our lives, the extremely high energy usage per person, the suffering of people at the bottom and ruining the planets biodiversity. Clearly overpopulation is a big part of this as there are so many of us around now to consume the planets scarce resources at increasing rates. Surely if everybody on the planet lived like the average western person it would likely have been all over by now. I believe David Puttnam conveys this challenge very clearly in his talk as we strive to make everybody consume as westerners without any regard to the external costs to our planet and all lifes habitats (including our own). Club of Rome basically said all this in the book "Limits to Growth" over 40 years ago and what we are seeing now is basically one of their scenarios playing out when many of the consequences form a perfect storm. I believe what we need to focus on is figuring out how to handle the fall as gracefully as possible, hopefully with technology that can sustain some of the burden of change - but it's one where it will be hard for anyone to choose to take part of it since it certainly means living with less for everybody. Question really is if we will let the poor bear the brunt of the fall or give everybody a chance.

text:
Well, I am perfectly fine with the fact that fossil fuels is basically the founding block of modern society and certainly the "green revolution" which  has nothing to do with environmentalism but converting fossil fuels into food. But I do believe we need to stop the train and consider carefully whether we actually made life easier or just enabled more of us to crash into the wall when the peaks of extraction were met. Certainly it has enabled us things that wasn't possible even to the point of creating people like Elon Musk which is actually fighting for a plan B for the human species by colonizing another planet. Computers and all we have around us wouldn't be possible without fossil fuels. But its been so many decades now that we have learned the hard truth about the effects of changing the planets greehouse effect (not by a small amount either, over a 40% increase of CO2 now) - but still we are not seeing any significant change in energy policy. The world really should be into a global Manhattan project now and whatever fossil fuels we do extract should be use for all the things that don't involve burning it. We have the means and the technology to transition away from fossil fuels for energy very quickly all over the planet if we just care enough and dare to invest into renewables - even if it means a short dip in wealth for the majority.

The moral case for fossil fuels is that it does not trump life in general. What I hear from the fossil fuel lobby is basically stretching the rubber band a bit longer, and a bit longer, without regarding the fact that we are wrecking our own habitat along with any other living thing here.

text:
+John Brookes, how could anyone not believe as you do? It's simple really. I used to believe as you do. That was me 5 years ago. What changed? Someone took the time, with patience and cordial data, to show how I was wrong. The emphasis wasn't on making me wrong. There was no name calling.

Feeling strongly about our planet and the future of humanity is a good thing. But you have to be armed with all the facts. If you have preconceived ideas, it makes it far harder for you to get new information. That's the "full cup" that needs to be emptied with humility.

Climate has been changing for nearly 4.5 billion years, but someone has made it suddenly "new," "dangerous" and "man made." But is it really? We see all the pollution going on in the world. Disgusting. We see all the corporate criminality and wonder when that will stop. And as corrupt as corporations are, we still get our news and science from those same corrupt corporations (hint, hint). Even the universities are corrupted by corporate money.

But let's look at the climate itself. Look at the following facts and see if you can find any fault with any of it. Provide sources or a detailed explanation for any disagreements you may have about it.

Fact: We live in an ongoing Ice Age. Just look at Greenland and Antarctica.

Fact: Global Warming made civilization possible 12,000 years ago. Did you know that the warming back then was +7C in 30 years? That's about 8x the current UN "scare story" which hasn't happened yet.

Fact: Our Modern Warm Period is a natural cycle coming out of the Little Ice Age.

Fact: The Holocene interglacial (warm phase of an Ice Age) has had 10 warm periods, 1 every 1,000 years or so (Ref: Alley, 2000). That's 10 natural warm periods; not 9 natural and 1 human+CO2. If CO2 were the driving force, our Modern Warm Period should be far warmer than it is (see next fact).

Fact: The Modern Warm Period is cooler than the Medieval Warm Period. Michael Mann and the Climate Gate scientists tried to rub it out of existence with their Hockey Stick fraud, but we know from history that Vikings grew crops in Greenland where we cannot grow them now. Medieval farmers grew wine grapes in England where they will not grow today.

Fact: CO2 is at starvation levels. Thirty million years ago, when CO2 levels dropped down to 800 ppm (2x today's), plants freaked out and evolved C4 species to cope with the CO2 starvation.

Fact: CO2 is far closer to extinction levels than it is to the Norm. About 15,000 BC, CO2 levels dropped to within 30 ppm of Lovelock's "Red Line" of extinction (Ref: "Red Line - Carbon Dioxide," Martin, 2016). We almost lost 85% of all plant species and nearly 99% of all food crop species. Imagine never having coffee, toast, pasta, beans, oranges, apples and nearly every other plant-based food you eat. The average for the last 600 million years was 1,600 ppm (4x today's).

Fact: Temperature response to CO2 increases is logarithmic and we've already gone past the saturation level at 400 ppm.

Fact: Global Warming is good, because we're in an Ice Age.

Fact: Global Warming produces far fewer and weaker storms. Wind blows because of temperature differences. You can see this by looking at the rising air from a fire. Eliminate the temperature difference, and that same air would not rise, and other air would not move in from the side to take its place. Global cooling will move polar cold closer to equatorial heat, making storms more frequent and more violent (Ref: H. Lamb, CRU; especially see his work on Little Ice Age storms).

Fact: Global Warming produces fewer droughts and smaller deserts. Rain doesn't happen by magic. It comes from warming of water and evaporation. During the far warmer Holocene Optimum, the Sahara was green for nearly 3,000 years. Today's wimpy Lake Chad was, back then, a robust inland sea rivaling the Caspian in its heyday.

There are a lot more facts that support the non-AGW viewpoint. In fact, I've written two books on the topic. But I recommend you reign in your disgust and do some study. Look at both sides from multiple sources.

author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text:
"Fact: We live in an ongoing Ice Age. Just look at Greenland and Antarctica."

We are currently in the interglacial period of the ice age cycle.  The ice age cycle has been going for about 3 million years, so not very long at all geologically.  But on the other hand, it is a  long time compared to how long humans have been on earth, and especially compared to how long civilisation has been around.

If we were in any real danger of returning to the glacial part of the ice age cycle any time soon, I'd be recommending the burning of as much fossil fuel as would be needed to avoid it. It would be a massive disaster.

The reason that the magical "2 degrees C" was chosen as the temperature increase to avoid is that when the world was consistently this warm, there was no ice, and sea levels were consequently a lot higher.  This too would be a disaster. 

I'm pretty sure that either of these disasters would put severe strain on civilisation.

In the end, I'm just in favour of avoiding disaster and saving civilisation.  It is pretty amazing that in the current interglacial we've developed our civilisation enough to understand and be able to influence the planet's climate.  It would be a shame to waste that understanding and return to short brutish lives for those fortunate enough to survive the end of civilisation.

CO2: again, I don't follow the measurements. Perhaps this figure is true but I wouldn't worry about it. Even if it were a problem (which it isn't) there is nothing we could do about it. Perhaps in Britain they could stop closing down power stations and build a few new ones. Fossil fuels. Are they that profitable? Try James Kunstler, who I imagine is not that different from the other peak oil people. They don't provide any refutable evidence and instead rely on attacking, shaming, and blocking any skeptical speech, data, and refute to their hypothesis.

You, my friend, need to take off your blinders and understand how science works.
The 'trends' have been refuted and proven false. The 'models' have been proven false by the natural climate itself. The 97% consensus has been proven false by looking at the very same information that was used to claim the consensus.
Literally every single bit of data provided to support AGW has been proven lacking.

See, your impression is that I refuse to believe all the data.
This is not the case.
The truth is that I refuse to believe unsubstantiated evidence.
If someone can prove to me, without a shadow of doubt, that warming is the fault of man and that this warming is dangerous, then I will become a believer.
I'm willing to accept that we MAY be at fault for some of the warming, but the truth is that even that hasn't been substantiated.
Seriously... Just go look it up yourself.
Find something that supports the hypothesis of AGW, and then research data that contradicts that claim.
In most cases, you will find more contradictions than data that will support said claims.

text:
¬†@Science Troll¬†
On the contrary, I am not afraid to hear anything or see anything that would refute my personal beliefs that I have based off scientific data. I'm only 32. However, with being 32 comes the fact that AGW has been shoved down my throat during most of my education.
It was taught to me in school, to which I believed it. It was only when I became an adult that I put away childish things.
Since then I have spent a bit over 4 years in the military and 10 working in the oil field.
I've seen tons of problematic issues when it comes to the accruing fossil fuels. However, Co2 is the least of our worries.
Co2 has been 15x higher than it is now.
Temps have fluctuated with and without any reaction from Co2 just over the past 500k years.
Temps have been increasing for over 300 years, yet we only focus on 120 years.
Co2 levels, when mankind came into this world, were roughly 5x higher than they are now.
Life on earth cannot be sustained if Co2 drops below 150 ppm.
Optimal Co2 levels are somewhere in the thousands.
Ocean levels have only risen roughly 7 inches in the past century, which is on par with previous centuries to which we did not produce Co2. As well, ocean levels have varied as much as 1500 meters in the past, yet we're complaining about millimeters a year.
330 years ago, we came out of the little ice age, to which times were hard for humanity at the time.
I can keep going, but why should I?
I'm speaking with someone that doesn't even know what AGW stands for, which could have been done with a single google search.
You don't even know what the most basic part of the conversation is about; Therefore, you don't need to be in the conversation.

text:
¬†@Shawn Benavente¬†¬†If those who go on and on about 'climate change' were granted 24/7 media coverage it wouldn't change a thing. Like I said... most people can not relate to it. Besides - your every day person is not the problem. Most people don't own manufacturing plants. Most people aren't designing - and then making - the next Cadillac Escalade. So even IF they were convinced - so what? They don't have the power to do anything about it anyway. Besides - not everyone [and that includes ME] is convinced that 'man' is entirely responsible.

That said... If I were in charge I would focus my attention on packaging. That's right... what those things we buy come packaged in. I'm a single guy. And the amount of cardboard and plastic wrap and containers that I throw away and/or recycle every month is a joke. Everything we buy should be wrapped in as little as possible. Consider a box of Cheerios. Does it really need to come in a big cardboard box? How many trees and how much pollution is being created just to attract our attention while walking buy the cereal section of a grocery store? It's silly. And consider those 'free' weekly community newspapers that end up at our door once or twice a week - whether we want them or not. How many trees are sacrificed for something that could just as easily be posted online?¬†

"Give a hoot! Don't pollute!" Was a big national anti-pollution campaign that began in 1971. It has since died off. But can you think of the last time you heard anyone say, "Don't litter!" There was also a TV commercial referred to as, 'The Crying Indian'. It featured a Native Indian man with a tear rolling down his cheek because he was surrounded by litter. We need to encourage people to care about the little things and the much bigger things will take care of themselves. [I believe]¬†

author: Doug Plumb

text:
I'm not an alarmist, I'm a realist...
Debates that speak to conclusions of whether climate change is man made or from the natural cycle is a waste of time.
Who cares whether it's the fault of the human animal with it's frailties and limitations, or if it's mother nature showing off her guns?
All I care about is that it is happening!!!
Fact: Biology 101: The human animal can't exist without habitat.
Fact: No human has existed above a 3.5 degree increase in the past.
Fact: The CO2 emitted into the atmosphere in the last 10 years hasn't been felt yet. There is a minimum 10 year lag.
Fact: Our oxygen comes from plants and the oceans
Fact: Our plants and oceans are dying
Fact: Global oxygen levels have decreased by a minimum 30%.
Fact: We are losing 150-200 animals a day.
Fact: Year 2100 climate models do not include effects of methane.
Fact: Abrupt climate change has been triggered due to release of methane.
Fact: The past has shown a 5 degree increase over a 13 year period.
Fact: 2 + 2 = 4 + degrees = Human Extinction
Fact: To deny any of the above, or to provide misleading information is to disrespect all the humans on this globe.

Fellow human animals of the world, I wish you the best in the next 20-30 years. 
Be good to each other, and live life the way YOU want to live.
Go ahead and keep burning the fossil fuels. I say this because you know you are waiting for the governments of the world to fix it.
They will not because they know, and you know, you'd be marching in the street if they confiscated your car, turned off your electricity, and shot all the cows, pigs, and chickens on the planet. To deny this is fooling yourself.

The human animal has had a great journey. 
As much as it is sad to see it ending for us, take solace in that none of us will be alone.

Food for thought: Instead of living in denial of impending death, think of it in the larger sense.
We all knew we'd die at some point, in some way...so other than the timeline....what's really changed?
From my perspective, the story of the human animal on this world, as brief on the geological time scale it will be, has been an amazing one.
Knowing there are only a few decades at the most left, gives me the opportunity to be truly free.
I hope it will do the same for you.

From my perspective, the story of the human animal on this world, as brief on the geological time scale it will be, has been an amazing one.
Knowing there are only a few decades at the most left, gives me the opportunity to be truly free.
I hope it will do the same for you.

text:
TheWalterSamuel21 
First off I am really sorry I mixed up pole and polar, since in german we call it "Nordpol , S√ºdpol". 
--I don't believe you are German. You may be, but there is no way to be sure and no way for you to prove it definitively. I simply do not trust you. You are free not to trust me if you wish

So since you have so many sources I will give you some aswell. Polars not melting significantly since 1979: https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2015/05/19/updated-nasa-data-polar-ice-not-receding-after-all/#674d4a5b2892 
--This is a misleading opinion piece, not a reviewed work of science. It was written by James McBee Taylor, the president of "Spark of Freedom Foundation" an organization that is closely tied to the "Heartland Institute", which, itself is a oil funded disinformation clearinghouse. Forbes is a financial magazine, not a scientific resource. Forbes is also a publication that has become rather infamous for "pay to publish" articles. Anyone can publish articles in Forbes, no matter how incorrect, misleading or slanted the articles may be as long as they have the money. Many unscrupulous people have done so over the last few years - I've seen it. 
If you want a true and honest representation of the science, you MUST go to the people performing the science- the scientists. That you do not know this is telling. In my travels I have found that Germans have very ordered minds and place a high value on logic. You do not, so I don't trust you

Another one on the CO2/Temperature correlation: https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2015/05/19/updated-nasa-data-polar-ice-not-receding-after-all/#674d4a5b2892 
---this is the same link. 

The climate changes and that is inevitable people like Al Gore are profiting on this making billions.
--Al Gore is a US politician and an old one at that. He was Vice President going on 18 years ago now. He's not that well known in Germany. You do not argue facts here. You replace facts with demagoguery. Al Gore is worth $200 million, not billions. And that he is very wealthy (like so many politicians these days) is irrelevant to the facts regarding climate change. Howard Hughes made quite a bit of money on warplanes. That he did is a irrelevant to the threat that was posed by Hitler. 

"but the fact is that this a normal occurence and the media today just makes the most out of it with butthurt prophecies."
--"butthurt" is a term that you don't hear too many Germans use either. In fact it's really recent American slang that boys who like Pepe the Frog and frequent Reddit use. 

Now I want to justify my statement from the last post: "We are talking about numbers like 0,005 degrees , makes no difference at all. " Since 1880 the temperature has risen by a shocking 0.8 celsius , expert say that 5% of this is due to our increased output of CO2, do the math 0,04 degress thanks to us 0,005 or 0,004 not so far of mate.
--I doubt you will do this, but show me specifically where "experts say that 5% of this is due to our increased output of CO2" - in context. Do you trust the experts for this fact (if it is indeed a fact) but not other facts? Do you pick and choose what facts you want to believe?
It's all so very simple - When my parents were born (about 1930), the world had about 2 billion people on it. When I was born (1961) the world had 3 billion people on it. Now the world has 7.4 billion people on. That's exponential growth. As the human population has grown, our use of coal and oil and natural gas has grown too. CO2 emissions have also grown. Humans are now emitting more CO2 than they ever have. 
CO2 ask like a blanket or a coat. CO2 acts like insulation. The extra layer of insulation that we are adding in our atmosphere is going to hold in more heat exactly as it would if you stood in the sun in a heavy coat. The experts you cited before say that the temperature will rise 2¬∞C to 6¬∞C by the end of the century.  But like I said, you seem to want to pick and choose what facts you want to believe


 "you think more CO2 =higher temperature - which is out of context completly."
--more CO2 in the atmosphere does indeed mean higher temperatures globally (If the power of the sun remains relatively constant).

You think you are smart and try to explain me thinks I know since I was a child, and you think that climate will continue in the same way consistently because the only variable is CO2 and we will soon live in an oven here, but current measurements show that you are wrong and that climate is much more in-depth and will always vary through time
--I do not think I am smarter, but I know that I am presenting facts as you present opinion. CO2 is not the only variable and I never claimed it was. Current temperatures are rising exactly as the models predicted they would. The models predict that as the world consumes ever more fossil fuel, greenhouse gas concentrations will continue to rise, and Earth‚Äôs average surface temperature will rise with them. Based on a range of plausible emission scenarios, average surface temperatures could rise between 2¬∞C and 6¬∞C by the end of the 21st century. Though 2¬∞C seems out of the question now

text:
The consensus regarding climate science is, significantly, not about whether scientists agree with one another. It refers to consensus of published literature, and by extension, evidence. 97.3% of all published papers which express a position on the question of anthropogenic climate change (that is, is it real, and did humans cause it) agree that indeed, the earth is warming and humans are responsible. 

The flagrant dismissal of scientific consensus as "opinions of the experts" misses the critical notion that we are not talking about opinions here, we are talking about the combined evidence and research of every scientific climate institution on the entire planet. Listen to the evidence.

in each example he uses describes dilemmas from their beginning till the end of reasonable acceptance of slavery as an economic need. (seat belts, addictive nicotine)

the problem with applying that scenario to climate change and human intervention is vast. knowing that science is based on observations, hypothesis formation, data collection, then interpretation. (which is always influenced by individual human biased)

one must look at the complete data set in order to make statements that are or seem to be true. when measuring climate change there is a very small data set. the earth being 4.8 billion years old and science only tracking weather for approximately 200 years. that fractional percentage of time is.000000000146%. if the idea that ice cores and other data can and has been recorded via sedimentary layers of the earths crust creates the opportunity for data going back a couple of hundred million years the percentage is still astoundingly low. ~ .00000416%. 

while i do not endorse pollution through irresponsible corporate goals overriding logical negatives that have no place in our modern society. i must admit that 400-600 PPM of carbon in the atmosphere is negligible at best. CO2 is food for plants. which creates O2 that humans need. on submarines servicemen are exposed to 5000 PPM of CO2 with little to no affect. 
the atmosphere that you breath while you read this is 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen and 1% other gasses. this planet has had times when living organisms were huge, some science suggests the atmosphere make up was higher in CO2 leading to giant plants that could sustain giant living organisms, proofed through the fossil record.

love your time on this planet. as my dad always said "when you come in to this room leave it the way you found it, like you were never there". hysterical climate change hogwash is putting profits in the pockets of both sides of this argument and the only losers are the people which aren't driving cars with clean fuels due to corporate greed.

author: LjV 209

text:
There are many problems other than climate change.  Climate change says nothing other than it has always been there.  What really is at stake and not mentioned are humanitarian global geological and anthropological stewardship.  This concept, of course, would encompass climate change, loss of species, rising CO2's effects, or lack thereof, dwindling fish in the oceans, rising sea levels.  To call it just climate change, misses the mark in its entirety.  The focus is wrong. Planet Earth can still easily turn into hell without burning another single ton of coal or driving a vehicle a single mile.  I think its time to admit that we, as humans, can live with climate change.  At the same time, why don't we try some planetary climate geoengineering? Space positioned Infrared blockers to renew glaciation, a world wide ban on dumping waste of any kind into the oceans, a serious limit on equatorial deforestation- to name a few.  The current warnings against warming being trumpeted might actually be keeping us out of an ice age.  Is it not true that for every 1 deg K increase in global temperature that 380 ppm CO2 is responsible for only 0.004 deg F rise in temperature? Or was it deg C? CO2 does not create heat, the sun does. Water vapor is 160 times more powerful than CO2 as a so called greenhouse gas.  Don't get me wrong, the air in China is bad, bad, bad! And it's
not from CO2!

text:
An analogy of a denier:

I have a heart problem so I go to a Cardiologist who recommends a valve replacement.
I seek a second opinion from another cardiologist, and I get the same answer.
I seek a third opinion from another cardiologist, and I get the same answer.
I seek a fourth opinion from another cardiologist, and I get the same answer.
I go to 100 cardiologists and 97 recommend a valve replacement.

In the end what do I do? I go to a dentist, and he tells me to forget about it.

author: AmnzeroUK

text:
Nobody would refute that CO2 is a greenhouse gas, that it is increasing due to energy production, and that this has to have some effect on the climate.

I understand you are trying to make this simple, but it's really not.  CO2 by itself is, at best, a very minor contributor to the greenhouse effect.  The whole argument relates to whether a change in a minor greenhouse gas will have such a large magnifying effect on other variables such as the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. And until we get a model that predicts temperature changes accurately, there is really no reason to pay much credence to prognostications about future effects.

Even if you are convinced by the warming argument, there is really not much we can do about drastically reducing CO2 emissions globally, especially with major nations coming into the industrial age like China and India.

Why don't we hear about other kinds of creative proposals, such as having coordinated plans to relocate urban coastal populations to safer locations over the next 100 years?  The usual conclusion from these kinds of talks seems to be along the lines of blaming evil industry and fat cats for killing the planet.
author: Fergus

text: Actually, asides from water vapor, CO2 is the next most significant contributor to the greenhouse effect. Why do you say that it is only a minor contributor?

text: +Catherine Mai Because it contributes only about 5% of the greenhouse effect. That is minor.
author: Fergus

text: ¬†@Fergus¬† Yes, but even if it is minor doesn't it still play a fairly significant role in the greenhouse effect? Also, don't you think it is a good idea for developing countries to get a head start on more sustainable development? I'm sure there is a way for them to maintain their economic growth while keeping their environmental impact in check. text: Jake W.   you are oversimplifying a  very complex ("chaotic")  affair in a seriously misleading way.   That is why so many academics who actually study the Big Picture  do NOT agree with you.   For example,  yes,  Artic Ice is melting... But it is more than made up for by the INCREASE in Antartic Ice Caps.  Etc, etc.  And  statistically,   predictions made under chaotic conditions are VERY unreliable.  So yes,  the Climate  IS changing,  as it always has.   But the effects  on the actual climate are scarcely perceptible on a world scale.

text:
There may be BS on both sides but all we have to do is look at history. "Silent Spring" was SO overstated that it was preposterous.  Yes we did have to stop man's encroachment on Nature in many areas but the world's population has continued to grow without the natural world being murdered as it were.

There IS no climate change. In order to "prove" it, all of the data has been manufactured. NASA has actually changed the data three times. The IPCC who were supposed to be climate experts it turns out were mostly post-grad students being led by politicians. Anyone looking at Dr. Michael Mann's "hockey stick" would be surprised and ask, "Were is the medieval warm period and the little ice age?" In order to make our present warming appear to be unusual he simply left that out. He claimed that it was "a local event" instead of the world-wide climate that geology shows it to be. Dr. Roy Spencer, head of NASA's weather satellite program has that data from 1979 onward and it shows only the normal weather variations. 

We know that about every thousand years we have warm periods interspersed with cooler periods. In fact this warm period is cooler than the others for which we have proof. Should we therefore ascribe this to man rather than warming? All of the Earth's periods of highest productivity and natures expansion have been during warm periods. It was an ice age that killed off the entire Dinosaur species. They weren't destroyed from a warm planet. So worrying about man-made climate change is pretty ridiculous.

1. Make a hypothesis
2. Predict what will happen
3. Test against observations
4. Analysis (determine if true or false, if false the hypothesis is false)

I do hope we come out of this wiser. Since we don't have a spare Earth, we need it to be survivable and thrivable. CO2 is good for many plants, but it is cherry picking to ignore the negative consequences that  adding CO2  has to agriculture. Plants need water, a temperature range, reliable rain cycle and gentle intensity for planting. Some plants do not do well with extra co2. Other plants produce more but lose their 30% of their nutrient value  Weeds tend to thrive. So do many pests while their predators (bird, bats) don't do as well. Soil that is subject to alternating drought and extreme rains undergoes a change in composition. It becomes less hospitable to planting. There's more, but the bottom line is that in the ideal world of the lab, some plants will do better until temps get beyond a certain point. The plant picture doesn't look so good the real world of climate change.Ôªø

text:
¬†@Joshua Eckhardt¬†‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã, the ocean supplies a significant amount of food for much of the world. It is currently absorbing 40% of the extra heat resulting from greenhouse effect caused by co2 & other GHG. This is good news & bad news. The good news is that the atmosphere would be heating up faster if the ocean wasn't absorbing this heat. The bad news is that the ocean also absorbs co2. This is causing the ocean to grow more acid creating problems for corals (home to 15% of marine life) and shell fish, as well as a plankton (forget name) that provides food going up the good chain.  The marine habitat is under threat and so is the food source of millions of people.
Okay, I wasn't totally correct about it being good news that the ocean is absorbing heat. I left out the part about thermal expansion. When you heat up water, the molecules expand, taking up more room. This causes the level of the water to go up. The same thing happens with the ocean. 40% of current sea level rise is due to thermal expansion. The rest is due to ice sheet melt. As the sea level rises it has to go somewhere. It goes on land and up rivers. Land that isn't flooded but is now closer to shore, as well as land near the now brakish river become poisoned by salt and useless to agriculture. Think Florida, land of citrus and produce. More than half of Florida may be lost to agriculture.  Think Lousiana, land of seafood. And California is having longer & more intense fire seasons, water shortages etc. These may or may not be caused by global warming but it does suggest we should not be over-confident that we can rely on it as a food source.  

Climate change is about more than plants.

 All denial is ultimately about choosing passivity over action. I say choose action.

text:
¬†@Joshua Eckhardt¬†¬† The conservative agenda very much uses the mentality of "I got ya."¬† When there was a spill into the Colorado River last summer, all I heard from the conservative media and their cohorts was "let's do away with the EPA."¬† Fine.¬† And replace it with what? Conservatives never offer solutions because to them the environment is totally expendable.¬† Yes, maybe we should reform the EPA.¬† But get rid of it? So utterly naive to think that big corporations like GE will watch over the environment for us (you know...the company that said "We bring good things to life" as they dumped 3.1 million pounds of PCBs into the Hudson River).¬† Or perhaps, Bill O'Reilly, or Rush Limbaugh will watch over it for us. Actually, speaking of GE, they have dozens of toxic waste sites that are being cleaned up with TAXPAYER (your) dollars. So, then Solendra fails and I hear about what a waste of time and money it is pursuing alternative energy sources, with relentless attacks on Obama. Instead of offering solutions or options that would foster alternative energy means, conservative idiots like Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio just want to keep drilling for oil¬† and mining coal. That's their solution. Sometimes I think that "Climate Change" is a distraction from an arguably equally significant problem: one of pollution and fucking up the planet in general. Toxins litter the planet. Nearly every ecological niche is being decimated for the sake of profit (conservative code word: "jobs") But who is profiting? Multinational corporations like Unilever are doing away with world-wide rain forests altogether, not for the sake of jobs, but for the sake of profit. Cruz and Rubio have voted against nearly every program proposed to protect the planet (and animals). In contrast, California is at least attempting to build a better state economy while simultaneously becoming more "Green." That is what my conservative friends would call a "progressive"
mentality. To a conservative, "progressive" is a four-letter word (as is "Darwin").¬† To the rest of us "progressive" is what got us here.¬† I take the tag "secular-progressive" as a compliment. For this reason, and many others, years from now we will look back on conservative agenda as retrogressive (the opposite of progressive) as we often do. "One of the drivers of surface temperature increase is decrease in global cloud cover as measured by satellites over the last few decades."

Please don't say silly things.

Clouds can act as fast positive feedback or as negative feedback, depending on how high those clouds are in the atmosphere. The clouds are acting as net positive feedback, in accordance with climate models:


"A net decrease in the Earth‚Äôs cloud, aerosol, and surface 340 nm reflectivity during the past 33 yr (1979‚Äì2011)
[...]
The amount of the longwave offset plus changes in atmospheric absorption determine whether the cloud plus aerosol change represents a net positive or negative feedback. The correlated increase in surface temperature suggests a net positive feedback."

"Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record
[...]
Our results suggest that radiative forcing by a combination of anthropogenic greenhouse gases and volcanic aerosol has produced observed cloud changes during the past several decades that exert positive feedbacks on the climate system."

"An Analysis of the Short-Term Cloud Feedback Using MODIS Data
[...]
Low clouds provide a strong negative cloud feedback, mainly because of their impact in the shortwave (SW) portion of the spectrum. Midlevel clouds provide a positive net cloud feedback that is a combination of a positive SW feedback partially canceled by a negative feedback in the longwave (LW). High clouds have only a small impact on the net cloud feedback because of a close cancellation between large LW and SW cloud feedbacks."

"Impact of dataset choice on calculations of the short-term cloud feedback"

text:
+MrSirGareth

"We could have dropped a CO2 bomb on Hiroshima and vaporized all of Japan...of course the whole planet would have become a fireball within a few moments due to all of that  "positive feedback""
"Strange "science""

The science isn't "strange". You're just ignorant about what "positive feedback" is. You seem to think that all positive feedback must result in a runaway effect where the Earth becomes a "fireball within a few moments.* That's a very silly belief for you to have.

You can have positive feedback loops in warming that don't end up like a "fireball" or Venus. For example, the positive feedback loop in warming can go on for awhile, and then be reversed by a negative feedback loop that cools the planet, often resulting in ice ages. That's what happened on Earth, as discussed in the scientific literature. Of course, by the time the negative feedback kicks in to sufficient levels, the positive feedback would have produced enough warming to have detrimental effects on humans. It's that positive feedback, amongst other factors, that folks like James Hansen are worried about. For further discussion, see the following Youtube video from 1:55 to 3:36:
"The Runaway Greenhouse Effect - James Hansen"

In that video, Hansen makes the points I just noted. For example, he explains that the runaway greenhouse gas effect on Venus is different than Earth's cycles between ice ages and a warmer surface where all the ice caps are gone. In talking about Venus, Hansen was talking about a scenario in which an irreversible positive feedback occurs. Hansen knows full well that that does not apply to Earth, since Hansen is aware of the cyclical pattern of ice ages and the other patterns I brought up. Similarly so for the IPCC and other sources:

https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-6-1.html

"For instance, a ‚Äúrunaway greenhouse effect‚Äù‚Äîanalogous to Venus--appears to have virtually no chance of being induced by anthropogenic activities."
http://www.ipcc.ch/meetings/session31/inf3.pdf


This has been admirably explained by potholer54 on multiple occasions, in Youtube videos such as:
"Monckton Bunkum Part 3 - Correlations and Himalayan glaciers"
"25 - Climate Change -- The "800-year lag" unravelled"

And in sources such as:
"Causal feedbacks in climate change"


In summary: please stop ignorantly assuming that positive feedback entails a runaway effect where the entire planet becomes a "fireball".

Nope. The scientific evidence shows climate sensitivity (both transient and equilibrium) to be above 1.1. For example:

"Implications for climate sensitivity from the response to individual forcings
[...]
Here we show that climate sensitivity estimates derived from recent observations must account for the efficacy of each forcing active during the historical period. When we use single-forcing experiments to estimate these efficacies and calculate climate sensitivity from the observed twentieth-century warming, our estimates of both TCR [transient climate response] and ECS [equilibrium climate sensitivity] are revised upwards compared to previous studies, improving the consistency with independent constraints."

"On a minimal model for estimating climate sensitivity
[...]

[...] the method of LS14 underestimates climate sensitivity by about 13%, correcting the estimates from the previous section, the credible intervals for transient climate response and equilibrium climate sensitivity are 1.292‚Äì2.937 and 2.330‚Äì5.338C respectively."

"Spread in model climate sensitivity traced to atmospheric convective mixing
[...]
The mixing inferred from observations appears to be sufficiently strong to imply a climate sensitivity of more than 3 degrees for a doubling of carbon dioxide. This is significantly higher than the currently accepted lower bound of 1.5 degrees, thereby constraining model projections towards relatively severe future warming."

"Impact of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) on deriving anthropogenic warming rates from the instrumental temperature record
[...]
Our results indicate that both the high and the low end of the anthropogenic trend over the past 30 years found in previous studies are unlikely and that a transient climate response of 1.6 (1.0‚Äì3.3) C best captures the historic instrumental temperature record."

What can I counter this with but this:

In 1982, when Irigaray's essay first appeared, this was an incisive criticism: differential topology has traditionally privileged the study of what are known technically as ``manifolds without boundary''. However, in the past decade, under the impetus of the feminist critique, some mathematicians have given renewed attention to the theory of ``manifolds with boundary''  Perhaps not coincidentally, it is precisely these manifolds that arise in the new physics of conformal field theory, superstring theory and quantum gravity.
In string theory, the quantum-mechanical amplitude for the interaction of n closed or open strings is represented by a functional integral (basically, a sum) over fields living on a two-dimensional manifold with boundary In quantum gravity, we may expect that a similar representation will hold, except that the two-dimensional manifold with boundary will be replaced by a multidimensional one. Unfortunately, multidimensionality goes against the grain of conventional linear mathematical thought, and despite a recent broadening of attitudes (notably associated with the study of multidimensional nonlinear phenomena in chaos theory), the theory of multidimensional manifolds with boundary remains somewhat underdeveloped. Nevertheless, physicists' work on the functional-integral approach to quantum gravity continues, and this work is likely to stimulate the attention of mathematicians.

As Irigaray anticipated, an important question in all of these theories is: Can the boundary be transgressed (crossed), and if so, what happens then? Technically this is known as the problem of ``boundary conditions''. At a purely mathematical level, the most salient aspect of boundary conditions is the great diversity of possibilities: for example, ``free b.c.'' (no obstacle to crossing), ``reflecting b.c.'' (specular reflection as in a mirror), ``periodic b.c.'' (re-entrance in another part of the manifold), and ``antiperiodic b.c.'' (re-entrance with  tex2html_wrap_inline1413 twist). The question posed by physicists is: Of all these conceivable boundary conditions, which ones actually occur in the representation of quantum gravity? Or perhaps, do all of them occur simultaneously and on an equal footing, as suggested by the complementarity principle?74

text:
An analogy of an alarmist;
My car needs a transmission seal, valued at $0.25, but I think it's a transmission problem, so I go to a mechanic, who recommends a transmission replacement, he has a former politician, down on his luck, come out and do a 1 hour power point sales job on why I need to turn my car over to this mechanic.

I seek a second opinion from another mechanic, and I get the same answer, and he shows me a wrecked truck from the zoo, in which a polar bear died because they had the same problem as my car, and got into a crash.

I seek a third opinion from another mechanic and I get the same answer,  and she lectures me that driving with a transmission in this condition hurts the environment, and that if I continue, Florida will be under water in 2 years.
(This story is from 20 years ago!!)

I seek a fourth opinion from another mechanic, and I get the same answer, and he hands me a brochure with a survey, which states 97% of all mechanics agree, driving my car with this transmission problem will result in catastrophic consequences for the environment.(Note: only members of the mechanics association were allowed to participate in the survey).

I finally read a manual, and consult some Ford designers who worked at places like MIT, the Princeton Center for Advanced studies, and were Nobel laureates,.....who don't expect to make any money off me,
and find out it was only a $0.25 seal. I fix the seal, save tons of money, and decide never to believe anyone who has political, financial and personal motives to get me to pay them cash.

text:
One thing that you guys are missing is that scientists don't become acclaimed by preaching the status quo over and over again. They get rich and famous by making new discoveries and are therefore incentivized to come to different conclusions than their peers (ie. Einstein proving relativity)

Also, science is NOT one uniform body of knowledge. It doesn't have a dogma that is set in stone for an eternity. It is the medium through which we attempt to find objective truths in this world. So, arguing that science was wrong at some point in history is irrelevant because the medium that proved that period's science wrong was science.

Also, the Nazi scientist analogy doesn't work because: 1) there was a clear political motivation behind their findings (just like oil companies that fund anti-climate-change research) and 2) there findings were widely disputed and received almost universal disapproval internationally while climate change is internationally accepted by peer review journals....

The nature of Government is incentivized to grow by it's birth. Obtaining votes is done by offering change, which more often then not involve increases in budget expenditures, and increases in debt (seeing as the tax revenues aren't required to balance the budget).  ]

So what motivation do scientists have to form conclusions before testing? If they reply to a call from studies into global warming, yet come to conclusions that do not warrant their further funding, there is one obvious motivation- to maintain import. Continued payment and status increases upheld by government use of tax payer monies is a boon for this previously obscure science. If you recognize the microcosms of incentive from every perspective along this trail you will see that this is no conspiracy, but the outcome of incentive forces at work across a large industry. 

It is perhaps complex, but to think that this is not influencing outcomes would be foolish. As this speaker highlights, tabacco companies had incentive to ignore  the harmful effects of smoking. So to is Government incentivized to increase it's reach without constraint. So to, in unison, are climate scientists incentivized to propagate their importance. It is no small.coincidence that as government control increases so to do climate predictions. 

As an example: It may have been addressed earlier, outside of these incentive arguments, there has been no true consensus in this field. In fact, the study by Cook which established this 97% myth has been complealty debunked. That is a confirmed fact which has been peer reviewed!! Yet no where has this been exposed to the mainstream. Cook has not been defunded nor disgraced. There are no consequences to misinformation within science!
