text:
Abundant means sufficient to meet needs. In this way, there is ample supply of all atmospheric gas, and thus they are equally abundant.

Equilibrium means the intake and discharge of oxygen and carbon dioxide by organisms; the most abundant gas, nitrogen is neutral and serves as the pavement, the foundation and the footings of Earth's atmosphere. Increases in oxygen result from plant growth, which consume carbon dioxide to do so. Carbon dioxide is liberated into the atmosphere from many sources, principally biological decay and combustion. Carbon dioxide is created from the decay of carbon monoxide, a direct result of combustion. Hydrocarbon combustion in vehicles is converted to dioxide quickly in the emissions phase, eliminating the short, several hour span of monoxide and harmful effects. The great majority of hydrocarbon combustion conducted for heat production on Earth is but a fraction of the carbon dioxide output that occurs.¬†

Carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere has not increased forty percent on Earth, as suggested. Spot measurements on the surface might reveal this figure; there are other factors not considered as they are not measured and unable to be measured, at this point.

Human technology does not measure the total volume of Earth's atmosphere; it is not static. Also not measured is the difference in concentrations at altitude. There is not a homogeneous mixture of Earth atmosphere gases; carbon dioxide is heavier than the two atom oxygen molecule and shows higher concentrations closer to the surface.

Humans measure concentrations in more densely populated areas, where human use of fuels increases the concentration temporarily. Long term study and analysis of gaseous concentrations far from human populations and activities, such as across vast, un-populated land masses and over oceans and at altitudes above these locations, across Earth's surface, would reveal differences not considered now.

The percentage increases and declines in oxygen and carbon dioxide are indeed much different, because the base amounts are so different. Gaseous equilibrium of these two substances has long been present on Earth, where the exchange in amounts is relatively even, by molecule. Thus one molecule of carbon dioxide, with two oxygen atoms is consumed by a plant, which liberates two atoms of oxygen, or one molecule, as part of its biological process. The carbon atom remains in the plant, along with hydrogen and is liberated when the plant dies and decays. Individual species vary this greatly, yet across any area of surface vegetation, the weighted average is nearly always one to one. This aspect of plant biology is not measured, as the total population of plants, trees and vegetable life is difficult or impossible to accurately measure.¬†

There will be no collapse of the human population from climate variation, which is beyond control of human beings. Human activity has not caused erratic weather and cannot, within all activities. We suggest human production of water vapor or steam could have a greater effect yet also immaterial against the total evaporation of hydrogen dioxide, or water, that now occurs. Even if humans were to liberate steam in material amounts, equilibrium of temperature would result and the average temperatures at the surface would fall. Increased precipitation would cause this.¬†

Erratic patterns of weather currently observed on Earth are set against a brief sliver of Earth climate history, and have as cause the inner planet temperature variations affecting sea water temperatures far below surfaces, where temperatures have varied.

The seawater temperature variations at depth cause the shift in deep water current, caused by faster rise and fall of water currents and layers, which behave much as do differing layers of air, yet operate more quickly and with greater effect, given the density of seawater and depth pressures.

Humans do not and cannot measure seawater layers or temperatures many thousands of feet below the surface, where the action occurs, as humans would describe it in English.

Magnetic field variations and their effect on the Earth's core alter the heat reaching the surface, most greatly affecting seawater. The hard surface to land interface is a far less efficient thermocouple, as Earth understanding knows well. Solid to liquid is vastly more efficient and were it possible to measure Earth crust temperatures one to three meters below the ocean floors and also seawater temperatures just above the ocean floor, in approximately twenty five to twenty eight thousand key locations, this would be apparent and revealing.¬†

We hope you enjoy this very simple insight into Earth understanding and physical behavior heretofore not studied and not understood. Much greater explanations of Earth operation and physical properties will be offered in the coming years, as we detect need and also willingness to embrace ideas not able to be measured.

Human scientific process correctly requires objective measurement before acceptance of effects occurs, yet this also places a large barrier to consideration of theories - or facts we offer here - because the ability to verify is not yet present.¬†

This view towards science will alter in the coming decades as technologies and capabilities considered impossible are demonstrated. We refer to an episode of a popular human television program named Star Trek; in this program, one episode mentions transparent aluminum. Indeed there will be demonstrated the ability to create a material with weight, strength and density of this metal and the transparency of glass.¬†

Our thanks and appreciation for your questions, and also our gratitude for the enjoyment we will have upon observation of the reaction to our statements. A great honor to be offering these ideas to humanity. What we have said here has not been told to humans by energetic beings guardian angel guides, such as ourselves and the permission for which we are eternally grateful to have been granted.

Be well and always.

If people are denying the all the damning in favor of climate change, then these same people should be denying any scientific evidence supporting all other scientific theories, unless you want to be a hypocrite. In all seriousness though, even if ¬†the cause of climate change isn't anthropogenic, you can't argue that the climate isn't changing. And with a changing climate comes drastic consequences. So maybe instead of arguing about whether the evidence supports that climate change is anthropogenic, use the time and energy to figure out solutions to stop it or methods to cope with it.
I happen to believe the evidence. In my opinion the best solution is to produce artificial trees that suck CO2 out of the atmosphere in conjunction with continuing efforts to reduce CO2 emissions
http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121004-fake-trees-to-clean-the-skies
If the Wright brothers could invent a plane by observing how birds fly, then why can't we invent something that sucks CO2 out of the atmosphere like a tree? Mother nature has already provided many answers to the worlds most important questions.
The great thing with this is that it could be economical. One way is that ¬†the CO2 could be reacted with water to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen. Those products can be easily converted to hydrocarbons to use as fuel. I recommend you read the article for the details. 
Also, enacting legislation to reduce climate change is good, but it takes too much time. On top of that, we as humans want instant pleasure which means we are not good at taking steps to reduce our carbon footprint because it requires effort and compromise. That's why I Iike the idea of the artificial trees. What do you think?

text: ¬†@ST007¬† In terms of its heat retentive effect, water vapour is the most prominent greenhouse gas. In terms of its practical consequence on the climate system, carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. Without carbon dioxide, there would be no liquid water on Earth, and no water vapour thereby, only ice. It's because of carbon dioxide that we have a hydrologic cycle to begin with.
author: Ryan M

text: ¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†  No, liquid water is liquid due to atmospheric pressure and temperature. The point being, that water is by far the predominant greenhouse gas, yet the whole climate change thing goes on and on about CO2. It's bullshit, not science.
author: ST007

text:
¬†¬†@ST007¬† When the Earth was newly formed, higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and methane facilitated the temperatures and atmospheric pressures required to sustain liquid water despite a much cooler sun. Apart from these gases, the Earth would not have sustained liquid water, and it would not have sustained water vapour.

The contribution to the greenhouse effect coming from water vapour is 60%. The contribution to the greenhouse effect coming from CO2 is 26%. Other gases constitute the rest. If the 26% greenhouse contribution from CO2 were removed, temperatures would drop to such an extent that Earth's liquid water would freeze, halting the hydrologic cycle and virtually eliminating water vapour. Earth would be a frozen wasteland.

Atmospheric carbon dioxide facilitates the existence of water vapour. Water vapour does not facilitate the existence of atmospheric carbon dioxide.

If you are a grown adult and do not grasp these most basic facts about climate physics, I don't know that you ever will. The illiteracy required to be so confused about these things is astonishing. Not only do you not understand basic climate physics, you do not wish to understand; you are more interested in clinging to your beliefs. Ignorance is one thing, but obstinate ignorance is another thing entirely. It is thoroughly depressing. Don't you care about understanding reality?
author: Ryan M

text: ¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†  Gravity, magnetic field. You know, I doubt that most people educated or not would have any idea about climate science. It's a highly specialised field. You have to read up on it, which you might want to do if you're interested in climate change. And you have to read up on both sides of the argument. Forgone conclusions are dogma and dogma is not science.
author: ST007

text:
¬†@ST007¬† There are not "two sides to the argument". There is only what's true, and what's true is determined by the facts and the evidence.

The facts and the evidence indicate that the Earth is round, and that it orbits the sun. There are not "two sides" to that argument, there is only what's true. People who disagree with planetary motion are plainly incorrect.

The facts and the evidence indicate that species differentiation occurs via evolution by natural selection. There are not "two sides" to that argument, there is only what's true. People who disagree with evolution by natural selection are plainly incorrect.

The facts and the evidence indicate that the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gases are the primary cause. There are not "two sides" to that argument, there is only what's true. People who disagree with anthropogenic climate change are plainly incorrect.

The truth is not a democratic process. It is not decided upon by argument. It is arrived at by way of facts and evidence. When you disagree with the facts and the evidence, you are plainly incorrect, because the facts and the evidence are true regardless of your private perceptions.

Creationists love to argue that their absurd fairy tales should be taught in science class because "children should hear both sides of the argument and make up their own minds." But this is fallacious nonsense, because creationism is plainly incorrect in that it is completely unsupported by facts and evidence. Similarly, climate deniers love to argue that their side should have a voice, so that "people can hear both sides of the argument and make up their own minds." This too is fallacious nonsense, because climate change denial is plainly incorrect in that it is completely unsupported by facts and evidence.

text:
¬†@CommunistPie¬† Wow! Convincing language. Ad hominem. I challenge you to think objectively about this:

Which is more conducive to life -- warmth or cold?

Temperatures on planet Earth over the last 600 Million years have largely hovered around 25-degrees C (~12-15 warmer than today). Much of that time, CO2 was over 1000ppm (compared to today's near 400ppm). And the oceans did not boil away or the planet burn up. Even the polar bears survived the far warmer, 3000-year, Holocene Optimum. It was so warm, evaporating more water from the oceans, that the added rain made the Sahara green for more than a thousand years.

Did you know that we're still in an Ice Age? The news doesn't talk about this, but we've been in an Ice Age for 2.6 Million years. The Holocene interglacial warm period of the current Ice Age is 12,000 years old. The average length of interglacials is 11,000 years.

If you are as smart as you think you are, then you might be able to figure out how cooling the planet (which anti-global warming crowd has already started) is extremely dangerous. Are you looking forward to humanity suffering another 90,000 years of perpetual winter? Chicago, New York and Paris under a mountain of ice? That would kill off 7+ Billion people.

Here's the NASA satellite data graphed by two climate scientists, showing 17 years without warming:
http://drroyspencer.com/latest-global-temperatures/

Yes, Climate-Gate was full of lies -- the IPCC, media, governments and you all lapped it up.

author: Albert Rogers

text:
+Albert Rogers 

RE: "I do not know what science your scientists studied, but it wasn't the metabolism of coral reef organisms, which a remarkable slight drop in the pH of the oceans can wipe out."

Who told you this bullshit?

The pH of the oceans are controlled primarily by oceanic temperature.  Warm waters expel carbon dioxide and cold waters absorb it from the atmosphere.  Thus colder waters are less alkaline ("more acidic" in the vernacular of the climate bullshit industry)  

It is the increased availability of carbon dioxide in freezing arctic/antarctic waters that make them the most abundant in sea life of all oceanic waters. They are the breadbasket of the oceans, not the warmer waters with their inedible pretty tropical fish.  

Finally if the oceans were actually warming they would be getting "less acidic" (bullshit term warning),  not more. 

pH variations of the oceans are routine, minuscule, and have no significant affect on life.    The soda water you like to drink is 10,000 times more "acidic" than seawater.  How deadly is it anyway?

This appears to be a normal cycle on the reef based on the tilt of the earth. Once the water returns, the reef recovers 100% within 5 years. As to the ocean temp being warmer..............800 miles away in New Guinea, the water is 2 degrees warmer than the barrier reef and the corals are doing just fine. By the way, cold water is less alkaline than warm water, ergo the acidification argument is pure BS. Nowhere on the planet has the ocean gone anywhere near "acid".

"This is again one of those obscure claims that sounds scary but doesn‚Äôt stand up to scrutiny. Ever since the acid rain scare, it has been realized that the public responds with alarm to anything with the word ‚Äòacid‚Äô in it. In point of fact, the ocean is basic rather than acidic (ie, its ph is always appreciably higher than 7, and there is no possibility of increasing levels of atmospheric CO2 bringing it down to 7; note that ph is a measure of acidity or basicness: values greater than 7 are basic and less than 7 acid.), and the purported changes simply refer to making the ocean a bit less basic. However, such a more correct description would lack the scare component. As usual, there is so much wrong with this claim that it takes a fairly long article to go over it all. author: George Applegate

text:
¬†@*****¬†
You would be right if you think that the vast majority of climate scientists think that all of human activity has some effect on climate. This is also what skeptics think.

If instead you believe that the vast majority think that man-made CO2 is the primary driver of climate change and that this change will be harmful, you are wrong.
author: George Applegate

text:
¬†@*****¬†
I figured that would be your belief, but what is that based on? In the Bray survey of published climate scientists, only 1/3 said they were "very much" (or more) convinced that more than half of recent temperature increase was caused by "human activity." The survey did not single out CO2, and since land use is known to have a large effect on climate, if they had asked specifically about CO2 the agreement would have been even less.

I realize that many scientific organizations have issued statements in favor of AGW. These statements are political. They are the opinions of the organization's leadership, not the unanimous or even majority vote of members - members are not asked. Obama has made similar statements and that definitely does not mean the unanimous or even majority agreement of the American people - we are never asked.

It is egregious that scientific organizations and government agencies (especially those funding research) have stated a position on a topic under research. Try getting research funding or publication if you don't say you agree with the official position. What other scientific topic is so political that agencies issue statements supporting a particular theory? Where are the position statements on dark matter? Or on what killed off the dinosaurs? Or the origin of life?

When the science is settled you stop doing research. Until then, efforts to discourage research that might cast doubt on dogma are anti-science.

author: Aesops Retreat

text:
So this asshat thinks that the science of climate change consists of creating a series of straw-man analogies and using emotional arguments.¬† Is this science?

Here is the science:

1 - The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is determined by the starvation of plants.¬† If there were no plants then there would be no O2 and a lot of CO2.¬† Plants eat O2 and crap out CO2.¬† They stop growing if the CO2 (food) gets too low.
2¬† - Plants used to be worse at this.¬† There are two mechanisms of photosynthesis.¬† Back in the (scary voice) "age before dinosaurs", plants were shit at sucking all the CO2 out of the atmosphere and so the CO2 concentration was way higher than now.
3 - The earth has just come out of a well-known cold period.¬† Before global-warming became a dogma, the 1880s were called the "little ice age".¬† Temperatures were obviously colder than had been before, as recorded by contemporary observers.¬† Rivers were freezing which had no recent record of such, etc.¬† Then we invented thermometers and started measuring temperatures.¬† And it went up.¬† Big surprise.
4 - The theory of CO2 induced warming is based on positive feedbacks.¬† The idea is that CO2 itself does not cause most of the warming, but that it cause a little warming.¬† The increased warming causes more water vapor, which causes more warming, which causes more water vapor, which causes more warming which...¬† And the water vapor causes all the warming.¬† If you think about this, it doesn't matter what kicks this process off.¬† Consider:¬† Volcano blows up causing more water vapor...¬† Generally in control theory, systems which have this kind of runaway behavior have already run away.¬† If someone tells you that "you should not breathe on that thing or else it will explode" then you should ask "so all the other people who breathed on it before didn't make it explode?".¬† The CO2 = warming theory is a theory that CO2 makes temperatures explode.
5 - The "hockey stick" you may have seen is the result of a field scientist not understanding math.¬† Michael Mann is an expert on tree rings who decided to try to figure out what the past temperatures were from his data.¬† He (like a good scientist) didn't trust his own data, so he go other people's data (coral reefs, etc).¬† Then he took temperature records from 1950-1995 (training data) and used them to make a linear regression (science talk for using math to guess what the relative strengths of different inputs are to influencing an output).¬† He found that his dataset matched exactly the training data, but that it made a flat line = 0 for the time before the training data.¬† Being ignorant of the math of generic linear algebras, he published this result.¬† The problem with this analysis is that if you take random data instead of tree rings you get the same result.¬† This is math, not science.¬† If the training data had been a U shape then the output would have been a flat line, then a U.

text: Bruce Frykman Francis Bacon was the first to formalize the concept of a true scientific method, but he didn't do so in a vacuum. The essence of science has been stated most accurately, if inelegantly,  by physics Nobel Prize winner Richard Feynman: "It doesn't matter how beautiful your theory is, it doesn't matter how smart you are. If it doesn't agree with experiment, it's wrong"

Feynman famously deconstructed NASA's attempt to explain their murder of the Challenger's crew by explaining the (known) reason that their shuttle exploded was because simply the  known faulty rubber seals were not resilient enough to work in freezing temperatures and not the BS they had been concocting to cover their asses. text:
I agree that science begins with observation and measurement and while reasoning (guessing) forms the basis of a hypothetical description of observed natural behavior, let's not elevate human reasoning, it is as flawed as all of our other behaviors.

Quantum theory is almost certainly incorrect and probably not just at the margins. It works for the things we ask of it but can't help us solve deeper mysteries. 

The models of the crystalline celestial spheres of Ptolemy provided exquisite detail of planetary and stellar motions, with one tiny flaw...what was the troublesome retrograde motion of Mars caused by?  Oh well it was only one little flaw to an otherwise nearly perfect theory of celestial motion.

Proposing that mathematics is is the purest form of science is rubbish.    This is like saying grammar is the purest form of literature.  Mathematics like grammar exists outside of the world of reality. 

I agree that there is nothing conspiratorial in the ideals of sciences or in faith.    However there is  a great deal of conspiracy, fraud and arrogance involve among the practitioners of both.  You are NOT claiming scientists are of a more virtuous class than politicians, teachers, priests,  and used car salesmen I hope.

author: Stephen Nielsen

text:
+Bruce Frykman

"I ask only that proponents of this theory, which of course provides the manipulators with the club they desire in which they seek to cudgel human liberty, only prove they can do the following:"

Based off of previous discussions with you, I know you're a denialist who will just side-step any evidence again your position. But I'm going to cite some evidence for the sake of anyone who's curious.



"1) Measure the "average" surface temperature of the Earth to 0.1 degree C of accuracy either in the present or within historical reach.   Beyond highly urban areas which produce little islands of heat like a kid peeing in the ocean,"

You're offering another standard denialist talking point about the urban heat island effect (UHI). 

The temperature records are not primarily from urban areas; there are, in fact, many temperature stations in rural areas, and temperature proxy records from cold regions (especially ice-covered regions where people can collect ice cores).

When you look at rural sites, there's statistically significant warming. When you correct for any UHI, there's still statistically significant surface warming and most of the observed surface warming remains; so the UHI does not work as an explanation of the observed surface warming. And there wasn't really a statistically significant difference in the warming trend between rural American stations that AGW denialists like Antony Watts like, and stations denialists don't like.

Here are some scientific research papers to get you started, providing evidence for the points I made above about the UHI and temperature rise:

"Influence of Urban Heating on the Global Temperature Land Average using Rural Sites Identified from MODIS classifications"
"Earth Atmospheric Land Surface Temperature and Station Quality in the Contiguous United States"
"Urban heat island effects on estimates of observed climate change"
"A Demonstration That Large-Scale Warming Is Not Urban"
"Assessment of Urban Versus Rural In Situ Surface Temperatures in the Contiguous United States: No Difference Found"
"Urban and rural temperature trends in proximity to large US cities: 1951‚Äì2000"
"Urbanization effects in large-scale temperature records, with an emphasis on China"
"Urbanization-related warming in local temperature records: a review"
"Evaluating the impact of U.S. Historical Climatology Network homogenization using the U.S. Climate Reference Network"
"On the reliability of the U.S. surface temperature record"
"Urbanization Effects on Observed Surface Air Temperature Trends in North China"



"2) Define what such an average means, what it consists of and what it excludes or why any of it is of importance.  The globe does not have an "average" climate.  It has millions of separate climates."

Which is as ridiculous as saying that:
"The room's air does not have an "average" temperature.  It has millions of separate temperatures."

Global warming is measured in terms of temperature anomalies relative to a baseline. Average temperature is normally defined in terms of the average of the minimum and maximum temperature at the site.



"Furthermore this defective theory predicts "atmospheric warming""

There's been warming of the troposphere (lower atmospheric layer) and cooling of the stratosphere (a higher atmospheric layer), which is what you'd expect greenhouse-gas-induced global warming.

Here are some sources on this warming pattern:

"A second smoking gun is that if the sun were responsible for global warming, we would expect to see warming throughout all layers of the atmosphere, from the surface all the way up to the upper atmosphere (stratosphere). But what we actually see is warming at the surface and cooling in the stratosphere. This is consistent with the warming being caused by a build-up of heat-trapping gases near the surface of the Earth, and not by the sun getting ‚Äúhotter.‚Äù"
http://climate.nasa.gov/faq/?

"Sensitivity of Satellite-Derived Tropospheric Temperature Trends to the Diurnal Cycle Adjustment"
"Assessing atmospheric temperature data sets for climate studies"
"Comparing tropospheric warming in climate models and satellite data"
"Attributing the forced components of observed stratospheric temperature variability to external drivers"
"Comment on ‚ÄúClimate Science and the Uncertainty Monster‚Äù by J. A. Curry and P. J. Webster"
"Identifying human influences on atmospheric temperature"



"3) Demonstrate the predictive accuracy of the just ONE CAGW theory (not the 30 to  50 of them)"

This is further confirmation that you're a denialist/contrarian, since "CAGW" is a straw man used by contrarians/denialists:

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."



"4) Explain how denying the availability of abundant affordable energy [...]"    
*"5) Explain how much cooler you expect the planet to be by 2100 by compelling huge segments of our economy [...]" 
"6) Explain exactly what the difference is between a "policy maker" [...]

Political/economic ramblings for you, that are irrelevant to the scientific evidence supporting the scientific consensus on anthropogenic climate change. What you're doing is inventing political/economic straw men, and then act as if one needs to defend these straw men in order to support the scientific consenusus on anthropogenic climate change. That's silly of you. It's as ridiculous as saying that:

"before I accept that smoking causes cancer, you need to discuss:
1) why it's OK to deny people access to cigarettes,
2) the precise number of people you expect to save by legally compelling people not to smoke
3) what a "policy maker" is."

Seriously, stop conflating policy with science.



"These will do for starters but this is such a target rich field I cant be expected to list all of the issues in one little post.  It requires volumes"

So like many other denialists, you'll move the goalposts:

"Of all the characteristics of deniers, repeatedly nudging back the goalpost‚Äîor the threshold of evidence required for acceptance of a theory‚Äîis often the most telling. The strategy behind goalpost-moving is simple: always demand more evidence than can currently be provided. If the evidence is then provided at a later date, simply change the demand to require even more evidence, or refuse to accept the kind of evidence that is being offered."

text:
+Albert Rogers 

I'm both skeptical and un-alarmed over the atmospheric gases either now or in the past.   The frenzy of the known lies that we are being told about this manufactured "crisis" are reminiscent of the "eugenics crises" that book-ended the turn of the previous century.

We know this fake crisis was only declared officially over at the arrival of our GIs at the death camps that were the outward manifestation of this previous made-up crisis. 

First,  it has been homo-sapiens raison d'etre to alter his natural habitat to terms more favorable to his existence for at least the last 50,000 years.  We thrive by dominating nature, not submitting to it.

Second, although it is really impossible to determine the percentage of atmospheric CO2 concentrations that owe itself to our industrial activities, it is and will remain a trace gas with virtually no effect on temperature and only a beneficial effect on the biosphere.  

There is a reason that our close planetary neighbor's (Venus and Mars) atmospheres are dominated by carbon dioxide and Earth is almost totally devoid of it.  Both our land and sea biology hungrily devours CO2 as fast as it can be made, with only marginal concentration variances established at some new equilibrium at or near the starvation level of certain plant populations.

The atmosphere is not a greenhouse, the oceans are not going acid, the ice is not melting, the seas are not rising (anymore) as they have been for the previous 12,000 years and the globe is not overheating nor are there prospects for any of this occurring at the hand of mankind.   

Even if any unproven slight warming were to occur, the net benefit would be a environment with more arable land and thus more suitable to human habitation.  

CO2 is a life affirming substance just like water and oxygen.  There are as there have always been the false doomsday prophets who seek only personal power at the expense of the gullible, the stupid, and th misinformed.            

I don't really give a rats ass over this manufactured crisis.  I want human freedom to shape our individual futures and want no one in charge of mankind's collective future.

Let freedom ring.

text:
+Stephan Nielsen 

RE: "The science says that the world would be slowly growing cooler at this time (slowly moving into the next ice age)"

The very shortest Milankovitch cycle, the precession of the poles,  is a 26,000 year cycle but there are two other major cycles: the orbital eccentricity cycle and the axial declination to the ecliptic are far more irregular and can take more then 75 thousand years.

While we have certainly been emerging from an ice maximum that occurred some 15 thousand years age,  The Earth is still deep in the current ice age.   The Earth is about now about 20 F degrees below where it should be on average.  

https://geology.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/ice_ages1.gif

No, I compare them to an "eyedropper" here is the arithmetic:  


Percentage of the Gulf of Mexico's of roughly 2,500 quadrillion liters (17 quadrillion barrels) that were fouled by nature's oil from Deep Horizon if the oil spill was 4.9 million barrels? (Wiki)

Here is the percentage:  0.0000000288% 

Now for comparison,  how much of natures own crude oil would we have to drop from an eyedropper into an Olympic size swimming pool to "pollute it" equally?

Olympic pool = 2,500,000 liters = 17,000 barrels
 
Amount of natural oil to pollute the Olympic pool as "badly" as Deep Horizon "polluted" the Gulf of Mexico
   
17000 barrels x (2.88 x 10^-10) = 0.000004896 barrels of oil
= 0.0007344 liters of oil 

There are 20,000 eyedropper drops per liter so we could "pollute" an Olympic sized swimming pool to the same extent the Gulf of Mexico was "polluted" by the Deep Horizon oil spill by dropping 15  drops of oil from an eye dropper into the Olympic sized swimming pool.

Or about as  much oil as leaks from the swimming pool pumps in a day.   

Natures oil from Deep Horizon has all been assimilated many years ago.

What does nature use to pollute the earth besides oil?

text: They're usually called wind turbines because they run a turbine, not because they don't mill anything.    But they are also properly called windmills, even though they no longer just mill things, because:  A windmill is a mill that converts the energy of wind into rotational energy by means of vanes called sails or blades.  They USED to be used primarily to mill things, but now that rotational energy is used to turn turbines and generate electricity, so they are aso called wind turbines even though the part that harnesses the wind is not the turbine, the part that uses the rotational energy thus produced is.

text: +CommunistPie That is incorrect. Both the RSS and UAH satellite data sets show no warming for over 15 years. These data sets are compiled independently of each other and using different satellite instruments. What is more significant is that the radiosonde data agrees, that is measurements from thermometers mounted on weather balloons. All three measure the temperature of the lower troposphere which extends from about 3 metres above the ground to about 25,000 feet. This is the part of the atmosphere where weather happens. Only the ground based weather stations show any warming, but how reliable are they? Not very. For a start, the raw data, i.e. the actual thermometer readings, show cooling since 2000, and it is only after they have been adjusted and homogenised by NASA and NOAA that any sign of warming appears. I'm sure these two agencies believe they are doing a good job, but at the same time  we must realise that if these guys did not find warming they would soon be hit by government cut backs in funding leading to job losses. Let us say that there is unfair pressure on them from government to make findings that the government desires. It would be a brave government employee who stood up and made Obama look a fool.

author: Aanthanur DC

text:
¬†@Aanthanur DC¬†

Obviously everything consuming or producing CO2 will effect the concentration of CO2 in the short term.¬† The fact remains that the levels of CO2 in the atmosphere are regulated over the long term by plants consuming it down to the starvation level.¬† This is not "disinformation", but basic science.

The volcano example is another area where you confuse the long term vs short term.¬† Again, control theory.¬† It is possible to have a short term effect which reduces temperature and also a long term one.¬† The theory of CO2 warming requires the CO2 from the volcano to cause warming.¬† The dust in the atmosphere will cause solar cooling, so long as the dust remains in the atmosphere.¬† So what a control theorist would expect is a right half plane zero in the transient response.¬† If a volcano erupts in a burst, you expect the temperature to go down initially and then up.¬† Because the theory goes that the dwell time of the CO2 is longer than the dwell time of the dust.¬† And all of these positive feedbacks (which you list even more of) are supposed to multiply this CO2 effect by some number around 3X-5X. This implies that the system is not stable, and even without humans it should have tipped over long ago.¬† We have observational evidence that this has not happened, at least in the warming direction.

Which leads me to the next point.¬† The ice ages and positive feedback.¬† It is pretty well certain that the ice age patterns are a hysteretic response to Milankovitch cycles through northern hemisphere albedo.¬† The solar flux goes up and and down and the northern hemisphere glaciers go into a positive feedback snap response due to the albedo.¬† This is a well documented, easily explainable positive feedback response which has been observed many times in the geological record.¬† A control theorist sees this as a nonlinear system with two zones of attraction.¬† If your theory if CO2 positive feedback were true, you would expect the end of the ice age to fly right by the glaciers melting and go right into the greenhouse you fear.¬† Consistently the earth has gone into net stable negative feedback once the glaciers melt off.¬† If your positive feedback from CO2 was as bad as the scare mongers say if "might be" then you would have seen it occur already.¬† Because that is what positive feedback systems do, they snap across the positive feedback until they hit another negative feedback region.¬† When CO2 was higher than now it didn't happen.¬† So unless nature cares about whether the CO2 was made by man or not, then we have evidence that this is not a problem in the geological record.

Regarding the hockey stick:¬† I do know what the fuck I am talking about.¬† I do this kind of signal analysis as part of my job and have extensive training in it.¬† It is just basic stuff about basis functions and random data.¬† You give me enough randomly generated waveforms and I can make any shape out of it I like over a finite region of the X-axis.¬† And the expectation of the area which I didn't try to shape is zero, with some residual random fluctuations.¬† This is exactly what you see in the various Mann-style temperature reconstructions.¬† And people have taken Matlab generated random data and achieved the same result.¬† So the tree rings are irrelevant to the hockey stick, except that they have enough noise in their data to fit whatever you want.

text:
¬†@Aanthanur DC¬†

I deleted a reply.¬† Sorry, I had thought this was a different thread.¬† Read it if you want.

Here is there theory of CO2 warming:¬† CO2 makes the air warmer.¬† This by itself causes little greenhouse effect (mainly because the CO2 line is already saturated).¬†¬† But the little effect it has causes more H2O (water) evaporated from the oceans,¬† This H20 remains vapor and adds more greenhouse.¬† This causes temperatures to rise more, adding more H20 And more greenhouse.¬† And so on.

The "vibration by a photon" you speak of is the saturated region.¬† Already there are enough CO2 molecules to vibrate between here and space to first order.¬† The real problems are:

* water vapor vs clouds.¬† one is greenhouse, one is albedo.¬† since water is the main positive feedback theorized. it is a huge problem that even the sign cannot be determined a-priori.
* convection.¬† greenhouse assumes a static layer of gasses.¬† Convection disrupts this layering in precisely the way to make greenhouse less effective.¬† If the warm air at the bottom of the stack increases its velocity to the top of the stack, then it can radiate out to space more effectively.¬† Temperature increases generally increase the convection.

A paleontologist would address the problem with the theory:

* many times before the earth had CO2 and also temperature more than today and WE ARE HERE


A control theorist would address the problem as:

* the earth seems to be oscillating between two semi-stable positions for the last half million years.¬† This implies a nonlinear system of negative feedback around the edges and positive¬† feedback about the top.¬† We are at the top now, and the "bottom bit" is not a happy place for us.¬† Unfortunately we are nearly due for a "bottom bit".¬† If you people could please try to think of ways to make the temperatures hotter, that would be nice.¬† Every time before this we had glaciers on NYC.¬† Please help us stop this.¬† And by the way, there is no evidence of any kind of problem from too much CO2 or temperatures.¬† In every way it seems to help life, farming, everything.¬†¬†

text:
¬†@Kevin Lyons¬†
¬†There are multiple lines of evidence showing that AGW is really happening. You don't even need models for it. The fact that CO2 is a greenhouse gas has been known for more than 100 years now. It traps heat, no matter how much you cry and plead, it will always do that.

By the way, you sound like an ignoramus about those models. It is clear about what you say about them. For one predictions are not the same as projections. Models ARE getting tested against observations that are made. What is more: The models that are used are unable¬†to predict the recent warming without taking rising CO2 levels into account. It is a clear indication that CO2 is causing the rise in temperature.

You also seem to be in the dark about what positive feedback is. Yes, we know water vapor is also a greenhouse gas and that it is abundant in the atmosphere, that's not the point. Temperature goes up -> more water vapor¬† -> temperature goes up, etc... CO2 causes the temperature to go up, this isn't disputed! text:
¬†@Kevin Lyons¬†
Water vapor increases the effect of CO2 (which is the positive feedback I mentioned before - CO2 just initiates the warming).

Again, not in my own words, but from wikipedia:

"If the atmospheres are warmed, the saturation vapor pressure increases, and the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere will tend to increase. Since water vapor is a greenhouse gas, the increase in water vapor content makes the atmosphere warm further; this warming causes the atmosphere to hold still more water vapor (a positive feedback), and so on until other processes stop the feedback loop. The result is a much larger greenhouse effect than that due to CO2 alone. Although this feedback process causes an increase in the absolute moisture content of the air, the relative humidity stays nearly constant or even decreases slightly because the air is warmer. Climate models incorporate this feedback. Water vapor feedback is strongly positive, with most evidence supporting a magnitude of 1.5 to 2.0 W/m2/K, sufficient to roughly double the warming that would otherwise occur."

An article from Science magazine, dealing with the same issues: http://geotest.tamu.edu/userfiles/216/dessler09.pdf

text:
summary or conclusion of those links: data and sources provided in links.¬†
Climate models predict upper atmosphere moistening which triples the greenhouse effect from man-made carbon dioxide emissions. The new satellite data from the NASA water vapor project shows declining upper atmosphere water vapor during the period 1988 to 2001. It is the best available data for water vapor because it has global coverage. Calculations by a line-by-line radiative code show that upper atmosphere water vapor changes at 500 mb to 300 mb have 29 times greater effect on OLR and temperatures than the same change near the surface. The cooling effect of the water vapor changes on OLR is 16 times greater than the warming effect of CO2¬†during the 1990 to 2001 period. Radiosonde data shows that upper atmosphere water vapor declines with warming. The IPCC dismisses the radiosonde data as the decline is inconsistent with theory. During the 1990 to 2001 period, upper atmosphere water vapor from satellite data declines more than that from radiosonde data, so there is no reason to dismiss the radiosonde data. Changes in water vapor are linked to temperature trends in the upper atmosphere. Both satellite data and radiosonde data confirm the absence of any tropical upper atmosphere temperature amplification, contrary to IPCC theory. Four independent data sets demonstrate that the IPCC theory is wrong. CO2¬†does not cause significant global warming.Note 1. The NVAP data in Excel format is¬†here.Note 2.¬†¬†The lower troposphere data is:¬†http://www.nsstc.uah.edu/public/msu/t2lt/uahncdc.ltThe upper troposphere data is calculated as 1.1 x middle troposphere ‚Äì 0.1 x lower stratosphere; where middle troposphere is:¬†http://www.nsstc.uah.edu/public/msu/t2/uahncdc.mt¬†and the lower stratosphere is:http://www.nsstc.uah.edu/public/msu/t4/uahncdc.ls

author: Robert Lyons

text:
¬†@Robert Lyons¬† I think we're on the same page when it comes to consensus. 

In the scientific method you propose a falsifiable hypothesis, calculate how nature would respond to an experiment, and run the experiment. If nature behaves as expected, that lends some credibility to the hypothesis, particularly if the outcome would've otherwise been unexpected. If nature behaves differently, the hypothesis is wrong. Move on.

The consensus that is talked about so much is simply the opinion that scientists will hold on whether the hypothesis will turn out to be valid, right up until the hypothesis is falsified. There's no place for opinion after the hypothesis has been falsified. After that, anyone expressing opinion in favor of the hypothesis aren't thinking clearly.

To my mind, we conducted such an experiment. The hypothesis that CO2 drives surface temperature was tested as CO2 levels continued to rise this century. So far it's not looking good for the hypothesis. Unfortunately the experiment was not properly designed with an endpoint, so while many think the experiment is done, others want the experiment to run longer. I'm in the former camp and think the latter are simply moving the goalposts.

text:
¬†@Robert Lyons¬† I largely agree. The climate model assumptions have been falsified to high confidence, including the posited positive feedbacks.

I think the science behind solar and cosmic influence on climate is as yet too incomplete to begin modeling, and until models have shown predictive value they are of little use other than as thought experiments.

One reason that believers will not accept that the CO2 hypothesis has failed, is a belief that only an alternative theory can replace the CO2 theory. It doesn't work that way in court and it doesn't work that way in science. 

In the court analogy, CO2 is on trial for illegal climate activity. The prosecution claims that because they don't have any other suspect, CO2 must be found guilty on a preponderance of correlation. The defense demands causation beyond a reasonable doubt, and is unconcerned about other possible culprits. The precautionary principle says that CO2 should be convicted and executed "just to be safe." It's a show trial in the tradition of Stalin's Lysenkoism.

text:
¬†@Robert Lyons¬† I worry that solar physicists are going to run afoul of the politics. If funding agencies that are vested in AGW get wind that solar physicists are studying climate interactions, their funding may dry up. My advice would be that they STFU about the climate implications of their research until they have something irrefutable.

There's a lot to explain. The present climate hypothesis makes zero effort to explain, let alone model, the previous warm and cool periods. Instead they want to "get rid of the Medieval Warm Period." Being able to explain those major past climate changes would be great, but there's no guarantee we will find proxies for whatever forces are involved.

Future modeling efforts will have to deal with the fact that the temperature data sets have been corrupted to the point where any efforts to hindcast will be trying to model thousands of politically motivated "adjustments." In some cases we no longer know what the real temperatures were, the original records having been destroyed.

One of the largest puzzles for me is the rock steady sea level rise since 1900. Although it is doubtless the result of ocean warming, it does not correlate at all with surface warming/cooling cycles. I suspect the deep oceans are warming steadily through some mechanism we don't understand. (It's quite comical to see AGW believers chastise deniers for not understanding the greenhouse effect, and then turn around and claim that CO2 skips all the physics and warms the deep ocean directly.) Clouds may be involved there.

text:
¬†@Cinqmil¬† Forcing due to atmospheric gas

¬†For a greenhouse gas, such as carbon dioxide, radiative transfer codes that examine each spectral line for atmospheric conditions can be used to calculate the change ŒîF as a function of changing concentration. These calculations can often be simplified into an algebraic formulation that is specific to that gas.
For instance, the simplified first-order approximation expression for carbon dioxide is:

ŒîF = 5.35 x Ln C/Co W m^-2

where C is the CO2 concentration in parts per million by volume and C0 is the reference concentration.[6] The relationship between carbon dioxide and radiative forcing is logarithmic[7] and thus increased concentrations have a progressively smaller warming effect.

text:
¬†@parabot2¬† In actual reality, Arctic ice is not recovering. It has not fallen past its record low set in 2012, but it continues to trend well below average. The decline of Arctic ice is not linear: some years will be better than others, but the overall trend is definitely down. We know this is true because the observations indicate it is true. If you deny this, it means you ignoring the observations, i.e., ignoring reality.

In actual reality, the expansion of Antarctic sea ice is evidence of declining Antarctic land ice. Antarctic land ice is fresh water, and as it runs out to sea it freshens the waters at the continent's coastal margins. During the Antarctic winter, this freshened water freezes at a higher temperature, leading to sea ice gains. During the Antarctic summer, this sea ice melts away, constituting a net loss of Antarctic ice cover.

In actual reality, ice at both poles is in a state of unprecedented decline. You do not understand this because you do not understand climate science.

You believe global warming is a "scam" because you are scientifically illiterate. To overcome this deficit, please stop reading industry-funded blogs and conspiracy websites, and pursue a proper scientific education instead. After you have pursued a proper scientific education, you will no longer hold incorrect views about science, and you will no longer say stupid things about science.

Scientific publications are peer-reviewed. Every scientist's work is examined by thousands of other scientists around the world. If someone publishes false or misleading data and submits it for peer review, it is very rapidly detected. The only way to corrupt the scientific method is to bring thousands and thousands of scientists in on the conspiracy, and to keep all of them in line indefinitely. It just isn't feasible. The last time this was attempted was when Dr. Andrew Wakefield published findings showing a link between vaccines and autism. The fraud in his report was detected almost instantly, and his conflict of interest exposed shortly thereafter. He lost his medical license and was disgraced by the scientific community. That is what happens when scientists publish false and misleading data for personal gain.

text:
¬†@parabot2¬† The scientific method proceeds by observing a phenomenon, formulating a hypothesis for its explanation, and then attempting to disprove that hypothesis by experimentation and evidence-gathering. Hypotheses are disproved until one emerges which cannot be disproved. When this occurs, scientific insight has been advanced.

Astronomers have conclusively measured the spin of a black hole by detecting the relativistic effects of distorted spacetime at the edge of its event horizon. By monitoring X-ray emissions from iron ions trapped in its accretion disk, direct information about the dimensions and rotational characteristics of a black hole has been observed.

The evidence indicates the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. Because this is true, it is necessary to apply measures to limit the emission of greenhouse gases. That is how things are in reality, where real things and events are true regardless of your private perceptions.

Eight separate investigations into the so-called "Climate Gate" scandal revealed no evidence of malfeasance, misrepresentation, or scientific indiscretion. The "Climate Gate" scandal was engineered by Ross McKitrick and Steven McIntyre, both of whom have political and financial ties to the fossil fuel industry, and neither of whom have a scientific background.

You are deeply confused and out of touch with reality. I would encourage you to keep arguing about black holes in the course of your science-denial, however, as this helps others see the level of scientific illiteracy that's required to deny anthropogenic climate change. You are helping to educate the public by exemplifying the idiocy behind your views. Keep it up.

text:
¬†@Vic Longdong¬† Fluoride salts must be kept within a narrow ideal temperature, and thorium reactors are resource intensive in their initialization, such that LFTR maintenance could be difficult and costly. Neutron budgeting in LFTRs is difficult to manage due to their inherent lossiness and propensity to generate Li-6.¬† The MSRE raised questions about the lifespan of LFTRs owing to corrosion caused by the circulation of fission products through the heat exchangers.

These are technical challenges with technical solutions, and given the immense safety advantage of their low pressure operation, LFTR technology is worth developing.

author: Vic Longdong

text:
¬†@Vic Longdong¬† LWR is an inferior technology to LFTR. There is no reason to continue building LWRs to the exclusion of LFTR development.

Of course plants use CO2 in their metabolism, and of course it is pumped into greenhouses to increase yields. Greenhouses are also constructed with panes that are transparent to visible and ultraviolet light, but semi-opaque to infrared light, i.e., heat energy. Similarly, CO2 is transparent to visible and ultraviolet light, but absorbs and re-emits light in the infrared spectrum, trapping heat in the troposphere and increasing temperatures.

text:
¬†@WATKYKJY GP¬† "They" didn't warn us of a coming ice age in the 60's and 70's. In the 70's a very small number of scientists theorized that the Soot and SO2 emissions from factories could cause global cooling. This never got past the point of theory, was never tested, and there never was anything remotely like scientific consensus. Since we passed laws to stop the soot and SO2 we will never know what, if any, effect they would have had on global climate. 


There is absolutely NO scientific evidence that CO2 levels increased AFTER "Climate Change" As early as the 1800s scientists had predicted that increasing levels of CO2 in our atmosphere would cause increased average temperatures. And the fact that you are looking at this as a "right" vs "left" issue is interesting. You should be looking for evidence first and then form an opinion. However, someone who looks at everything from a political viewpoint tends to do the opposite. They form an opinion first, then look for "evidence" to support that opinion. The fact that you state that you are neither "left" nor "right" doesn't take away the fact that that you brought politics into your "argument" and even mentioned Al Gore. A person who wants to be informed on a subject would look to people who are experts on that subject.



The experts in this case are Climate Scientists - the people whose job it is to study cliimate and weather. They are Meteorologists,  Astrophysicists. Atmospheric Physicists, Hydroclimatologists, and other scientists. They do not work for political "think tanks" and big oil. Scientists are not "right" or "left". Although each of them may subscribe to some political viewpoint, this is not how science works and political viewpoints should not ever drive a scientists studies. Scientists look for evidence first, then form opinions. There have been many honest skeptics within the scientific community, each of them raising honest questions regarding possible other causes of current Climate Change. The end result is that each and every other possible source has been proven NOT to the be the cause of Climate Change that we are dealing with. There is overwhelming  scientific consensus regarding Climate Change because there is overwhelming evidence of it. The overwhelming evidence shows that human activity, primarily burning of fossil fuels is causing current Global Warming because of the unprecendented amounts of CO2 being pumped into the atmosphere..


And, by the way, our "Climate" doesn't change four times a year. Climate refers to the general trend of temperatures over a long span of time. Weather and Climate are different things.

text:
¬†@jay762360¬† A doubling of CO2 on it's own, raises the temperature of the earth by about 1'C. As this happens, the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere increases and this allows more ice to melt, reducing the reflectivity of the earths surface. Multiple sources from the IPCC and several other sources agree that this positive feedback loop will likely result in the 3'C rise in temperature. That temperature rise means even more water vapor can be held by the atmosphere producing more floods and severe storms.

We know it's man made CO2 because the isotope carbon 13 is less common in fossel fuels than it is in nature, and the amount of carbon 13 is declining even with the rise in CO2. While you might think, the planet emits way more CO2 than humans, "Which is correct." the system was in balance with the land and oceans absorbing the amount it emits. Roughly 780 gigatons. We as people, emit about 30, but this extra CO2 is not being completely absorbed and hence where the problem is coming from. This is why CO2 is rising beyond its natural balance of about 180-280 parts per million, and is now pushing beyond 400.

As the ice caps melt and sea levels rise countries like the Philippines and Indonesia will actually have to be completely evacuated as they will no longer be able to sustain human life with no fresh water. Many areas in china are also on low lying land and this will cause problems for them as well, both in fresh water and flood issues. Storms will get stronger and stronger, like the jump from Hurricane Wilma to Typhoon Haiyan and cause even heavier damage along coastal cities in the US and Canada. So overall, while it will no doubt hurt the economy for now, we can afford it. We can't afford the loss of dozens of major cities and displaced people that are sure to follow as the climate finalizes it's changes. By the time it is done, we will be at a population of about 12 billion people. That's a shitton of mouths to feed after literally billions of acres of farmlands, fresh water sources and species are eradicated by changes in the climate.

text:
¬†@Garbad Kishkashta¬† There is a difference between honest skepticism and outright denial. A skeptic looks for evidence and their opinions are based on evidence. A true skeptic works to advance science by looking for, and providing evidence of something. A denier is a completely different sort of person. A denier either continues to advance "proof" that has already been proven incorrect, or, worse, simply cherry picks evidence, engages in false logic, and uses other trickery to advance a viewpoint.


A true skeptic bases their opinion on facts and evidence and a denier tries to use false facts and cherry picked "evidence", as well as other tactics, to advance their opinion. They are complete opposites of each other. 


Climate Scientists are people who are skeptical, as are all scientists. They have been looking for and studying the evidence for decades. The evidence is overwhelming, and therefore an overwhelming majority of scientists agree - current Climate change is real, and is caused by human activity. They may not all agree on exactly how much and how fast global temperatures are and will be affected, but, there is vast, undeniable consensus among Climate Scientists as to the fact of Climate Change and the evidence that it is caused by human activity.

author: Peter Cuomo

text:
¬†@Garbad Kishkashta¬† I am somewhat familiar with Professor Lindzen. He is on the advisory board of a foundation in the UK that is concerned with undoing any policy changes that might mitigate the effects of Global Warming.


 I am also familiar with the fact that most Climate Scientists agree that the questions that he has raised has offered decent food for thought, but, in the end, each of his arguments has been proven incorrect by the evidence.


There have been a great many scientists that have looked at his work, since this is what science is all about - trying to get to the truth of the matter. In one of his talks, sponsored by the Campaign to Repeal the Climate Change Act, scientists point out the many problems with his "findings" and assertions. First, he rests most of his criticism of other climate scientists on the fact that there are some unknowns and uncertainties regarding some aspects of cloud feedback processes . He therefore makes assertions that because there are some uncertainties that scientists know nothing. This is practically his whole basis for discounting what virtually every other scientist in the world agrees on. They go on to point out so many inconsistencies and outright fallacies in his presentation that I am not going to bother regurgitating them here.


I don't agree with the majority BECAUSE they are the majority. As a scientist myself, I agree with the majority because their opinion is based on evidence. Over the many decades that Climate Scientists have been studying this issue, subjecting their study to true skepticism, they have yet to come up with anything that fits the data other than CO2 and other greenhouse gases that we are pumping into the atmosphere is causing the current Climate Change reality. 


I will continue looking at this issue because it is the most important issue facing our society. The good news is that since this is a problem we are causing ourselves, if we have the will and the good sense, we can solve it. We did a pretty good job on Acid Rain and looks like possibly on the Ozone problem by facing the facts and doing something about it. Good for us. I hope we also do something in this case before too much of the damage is irreversible.

If his assertions are supported by evidence I will be happy to acknowledge it. As a scientist I am interested in the truth of nature and the workings of the system in which I live, and have no need or desire to fool myself.

text:
+Belloran24

Here is an excellent response to Ted's Bullshit:

" Paris climate agreement was never about climate science. Anchored in the premise that climate science is ‚Äúsettled,‚Äù the accord seeks to dramatically change humanity‚Äôs energy supply. Here, the matter really is settled: It‚Äôs not going to happen.

Paris advocates assert that, despite President Donald Trump‚Äôs decision to pull out of the agreement, we face an inevitable transition to a multitude of new low-carbon energy technologies that will consign hydrocarbons‚Äîoil, natural gas, and coal‚Äîto history‚Äôs dust heap. All we need to birth the new energy future are the right ‚Äúincentives,‚Äù which Paris provides: The only way to meet aspirational carbon emissions reductions is to replace hydrocarbons.


This so-called multitude of options actually distills to just three things: biofuels, windmills, and solar panels. Some environmentalists include nuclear fission as well. There‚Äôs no new physics here: The first fission reaction was in 1939, the first photovoltaic cell was created in 1954, windmills date to the Middle Ages, and making alcohol (the dominant biofuel) predates recorded history.


But, say Paris supporters, all we need are moonshot government programs to see energy tech emulate the ‚ÄúMoore‚Äôs Law‚Äù progress that happened in computing (the doubling in computer power every two years). Yet to their inconvenience, the physics of energy won‚Äôt cooperate.

Fueling humanity is not like putting a few people on the moon. It‚Äôs like putting everybody on Earth on the moon‚Äîpermanently. No amount of money obviates the costs of fighting gravity. But pundits in awe of Silicon Valley‚Äôs prowess analogize today‚Äôs green energy companies to the disruption of landline phone businesses after the advent of cell phones or the disruption of taxis by Uber.

Unfortunately, the physics of energy production scales in exactly the opposite direction of the physics of information production. If aircraft, for example, followed Moore‚Äôs Law, a loaded Boeing 777 could reach Japan from New York by burning a housefly‚Äôs weight in fuel. Engineers and mathematicians can trick bytes to go faster and slip into ever smaller spaces, but only in science fiction are similar tricks possible with physical objects or humans.

Better technology has brought solar and wind costs down dramatically in the past decade. And, fueled by over $100 billion in subsidies, while wind and solar have increased 10-fold over a decade, they still supply, respectively, just 0.3% and 2% of America‚Äôs energy.


Remember biofuels? Ten years ago Silicon Valley legend Vinod Khosla famously predicted that with biofuels there is ‚Äúno doubt that 100% of our gasoline use can be displaced in the next 25 years.‚Äù Now, despite 40% of America‚Äôs corn crop used distilled into alcohol, that supplies barely 5% of U.S. transportation. No one expects America or the world to get anywhere close to Khosla‚Äôs forecast.

But there is a stubborn idea that more money‚Äîsubsidies, tax incentives, grants, or enforced standards‚Äîwill make solar and wind 10 times cheaper yet again. While all technologies get better over time, they also approach physics‚Äô limits eventually. Aircraft turbine manufacturers brag about single-digit percentage gains in fuel efficiency precisely because those machines are near thermodynamic limits in converting heat to thrust.

Solar cells and wind turbines are now in the same boat. There are no game-changing advances left in the core technologies; both are now on the curve of diminishing returns. (Biofuels crossed that Rubicon centuries ago.) Nor are there big gains in economies of scale for the underlying components‚Äîconcrete, steel, fiberglass, silicon, wires, and glass are all already in mass production.

If we want a different energy revolution, we‚Äôll need new discoveries in the physical sciences. That can only emerge from basic research, not from more subsidies for yesterday‚Äôs technologies.


Meanwhile, the world‚Äôs nearly 8 billion people and $80 trillion economy depend on hydrocarbons to supply over 80% of global energy; oil fuels 98% of transportation. Meaningful changes to this status quo won‚Äôt come from the Paris agreement with or without the U.S., unless there‚Äôs a revolution in physics. And the latter will require very different priorities. Perhaps it‚Äôs time to chase real science."

text: ¬†@Justaperson¬† While I believe in climate change in so far as climate change is a phenomenon that has occurred over many aeons, since the beginning of creation, I am inclined to question anthropomorphic climate change (The climate change which suggests that catastrophic Global Warming or Global cooling is driving primarily by mankind)  When there is evidence to suggest that far more carbon emissions are emitted by nature, some 10,000 times more, than there has by human activity; and since we as mankind are also part of the natural environment in that simply by the very process of  breathing we breathe out CO2, then does count as natural or man-made? Or are we referring more to the burning of fossil fuels, which is comprised more of hydrogen water vapours, which are in fact a greenhouse gas than CO2; or Methane-gas another well-known greenhouse gas, which again is not CO2.  If people who profess to care so much about saving really cared then why are we not looking at ways to reduce our carbon emissions by:¬†1) Reducing immigration - by reducing immigration numbers into the country we also reduce the need for the amount of development, which equals fewer trees being bulldozed, which take in CO2, fewer cars on the road and lower rates of crime with the added benefits of more employment. 2) More coal-fired power stations, which as opposed to renewable energies being on offer which have a large carbon footprint require large amounts of energy to power them and are unsustainable, only have a comparably small footprint.  These would also drive down the costs of electricity and create more jobs.
